794619_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	American Woodmark Corporation ( American Woodmark or the Company ) manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	American Woodmark was incorporated in 1980 by the four principal managers of the Boise Cascade Cabinet Division through a leveraged buyout of that division.
794619_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	American Woodmark was operated privately until 1986 when it became a public company through a registered public offering of its common stock.
794619_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	American Woodmark currently offers framed stock cabinets in approximately 500 different cabinet lines, ranging in price from relatively inexpensive to medium-priced styles.
794619_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	Styles vary by design and color from natural wood finishes to low-pressure laminate surfaces.
794619_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	The product offering of stock cabinets includes 83 door designs in 18 colors.
794619_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	Stock cabinets consist of a common box with standard interior components and a maple, oak, cherry, or hickory front frame, door and/or drawer front.
794619_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Products are primarily sold under the brand names of American Woodmark , Timberlake , Shenandoah Cabinetry , Potomac , and Waypoint Living Spaces .
794619_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	American Woodmark s products are sold on a national basis across the United States to the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	The Company services these markets through three primary channels: home centers, builders, and independent dealers and distributors.
794619_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company provides complete turnkey installation services to its direct builder customers via its network of nine service centers that are strategically located throughout the United States.
794619_11_ITEM1_P5_S1	The Company distributes its products to each market channel directly from four assembly plants through a third party logistics network.
794619_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	The primary raw materials used include hard maple, oak, cherry, soft maple, and hickory lumber and plywood.
794619_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	Additional raw materials include paint, particleboard, manufactured components, and hardware.
794619_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company currently purchases paint from one supplier; however, other sources are available.
794619_11_ITEM1_P6_S3	Other raw materials are purchased from more than one source and are readily available.
794619_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	American Woodmark operates in a highly fragmented industry that is composed of several thousand local, regional, and national manufacturers.
794619_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	The Company s principal means for competition is its breadth and variety of product offering, expanded service capabilities, geographic reach and affordable quality.
794619_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	The Company believes it is one of the three largest manufacturers of kitchen cabinets in the United States.
794619_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company s business has historically been subject to seasonal influences, with higher sales typically realized in the second and fourth fiscal quarters.
794619_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	General economic forces and changes in the Company s customer mix have reduced seasonal fluctuations in revenue over the past few years.
794619_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	The Company does not consider its level of order backlog to be material.
794619_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	In recognition of the cyclicality of the housing industry, the Company s policy is to operate with a minimal amount of financial leverage.
794619_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	The Company regularly maintains a debt to capital ratio below 15%, and working capital exclusive of cash of less than 6% of net sales.
794619_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	At April 30, 2011, debt to capital was 13.8%, and working capital net of cash was 3.1% of net sales.
794619_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	During the last fiscal year, American Woodmark had two primary customers, The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc., which together accounted for approximately 73% of the Company s sales in its fiscal year ended April 30, 2011 (fiscal 2011).
794619_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	The loss of either customer would have a material adverse effect on the Company.
794619_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	As of May 31, 2011, the Company had 3,693 employees.
794619_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	Approximately 10% of the Company s employees are represented by labor unions.
794619_11_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes that its employee relations are good.
794619_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	American Woodmark s annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, proxy statements, and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge on the Company s web site at www.americanwoodmark.com as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
794619_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	The contents of the Company s web site are not, however, part of this report.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	There are a number of business risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These risks and uncertainties could cause future results to differ from past performance or expected results, including results described in statements elsewhere in this report that constitute "forward-looking statements" under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to the Company or it currently believes to be immaterial also may adversely impact the business.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Should any risks or uncertainties develop into actual events, these developments could have material adverse effects on the Company s business, financial condition, and results of operations.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition are discussed in this report, including in Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations under the headings Forward-Looking Statements, Market Risks, and Outlook for Fiscal 2012 .
794619_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our business relies on remodeling activity and residential construction.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The Company s results of operations are affected by levels of home improvement and residential construction activity, including repair and remodeling and new construction.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Job creation levels, interest rates, availability of credit, energy costs, consumer confidence, national and regional economic conditions, and weather conditions and natural disasters can significantly impact levels of home improvement and residential construction activity.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our future financial performance depends in part on the success of our new product development and other growth strategies.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	The Company has increased its emphasis on new product development in recent years and continues to focus solely on organic growth.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Consequently, the Company s financial performance will, in part, reflect its success in implementing its growth strategies in its existing markets and in introducing new products.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The loss of, or a reduction in business from, either of our key customers would have a material adverse effect on our business.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The size and importance to the Company of its two largest customers is significant.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	These customers could make significant changes in their volume of purchases and could otherwise significantly affect the terms and conditions on which the Company does business.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Sales to The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc. were approximately 73% of total company sales for fiscal 2011.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Although builders, dealers, and other retailers represent other channels of distribution for the Company's products, an unplanned loss of a substantial portion of sales to The Home Depot or Lowe s Companies, Inc. would have a material adverse impact on the Company.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Our operating results are affected by the cost and availability of raw materials.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Because the Company is dependent on outside suppliers for raw material needs, it must obtain sufficient quantities of quality raw materials from its suppliers at acceptable prices and in a timely manner.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	The Company has no long-term supply contracts with its key suppliers.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P5_S3	A substantial decrease in the availability of products from the Company s suppliers, the loss of key supplier arrangements, or a substantial increase in the cost of its raw materials could adversely impact the Company s results of operations.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We may not be able to maintain or raise the prices of our products in response to inflation and increasing costs.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Short-term market and competitive pressures may prohibit the Company from raising prices to offset inflationary raw material and freight costs, which would adversely impact profit margins.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	The economic recession is adversely impacting demand for the housing industry.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Through fiscal year 2011, the Company s sales levels have fallen by 46% from their peak levels in 2006.
794619_11_ITEM1A_P7_S2	If market conditions continue to decline, the Company s sales, earnings, and cash flow would continue to be adversely impacted.

794619_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	In addition, the Company leases 1 manufacturing facility in Hardy County, West Virginia and owns 10 manufacturing facilities located primarily in the eastern United States.
794619_11_ITEM2_P0_S2	The Company also leases 9 primary service centers, 2 satellite service centers, and 3 additional office centers located throughout the United States that support the sale and distribution of products to each market channel.
794619_11_ITEM2_P0_S3	The Company considers its properties suitable for the business and adequate for its needs.

794619_11_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims, and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_11_ITEM3_P0_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_11_ITEM3_P1_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_11_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company accounts for these loss contingencies in accordance with ASC 450.
794619_11_ITEM3_P2_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_11_ITEM3_P2_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible or remote, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_11_ITEM3_P2_S2	Where no loss estimate range can be made, the Company and its counsel perform a worst-case estimate.
794619_11_ITEM3_P2_S3	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_11_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of estimated loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible was not material as of April 30, 2011.
794619_11_ITEM3_P4_S0	Also see the information under Legal Matters under Note K Commitments and Contingencies to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report under Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data .

794619_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	American Woodmark Corporation manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	Its products are sold on a national basis directly to home centers, major builders and home manufacturers and through a network of independent dealers and distributors.
794619_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	At April 30, 2011, the Company operated 11 manufacturing facilities and 9 service centers across the country.
794619_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	During the Company s fiscal year that ended on April 30, 2011 (fiscal 2011), the Company experienced a continuation of difficult housing market conditions that have prevailed since the housing market peaked five years ago.
794619_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	Several emerging positive factors were overshadowed by negatives.
794619_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	Positive factors included private sector job creation of approximately 1.3 million during the Company s fiscal 2011 and mortgage delinquencies, as reported by the Mortgage Banking Association, reaching their lowest levels in two years.
794619_11_ITEM7_P5_S3	Negative factors included Gross Private Residential Fixed Investment, as reported by the U.S. Department of Commerce, declining during the third and fourth calendar quarters of 2010 and first calendar quarter of 2011 and housing starts declining by 17% and 5% during the three- and twelve-month periods ended April 30, 2011, respectively.
794619_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	In new home construction, housing starts reached a 50-year low of only 554,000 during fiscal 2011, a decline of 74% compared with 2.1 million housing starts in fiscal 2006.
794619_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	In the remodeling market, sales of existing homes during fiscal 2011 were 4.9 million homes, a 10% reduction from the prior year s Federal housing stimulus-aided levels and the median home price of houses sold declined by 2%.
794619_11_ITEM7_P6_S2	Although existing home sales levels have stabilized, the combination of declining home prices and elevated unemployment levels have led to relatively weak consumer confidence, causing the Company s overall market to decline by approximately 5% during fiscal 2011, based upon sales reported by the Kitchen Cabinet Manufacturers Association.
794619_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Faced with these challenging market conditions, the Company s largest remodeling customers chose to utilize aggressive sales promotions during the fall 2010 and spring 2011 selling seasons to boost sales.
794619_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	These promotions consisted of free products and cash discounts to consumers based upon the amount and/or type of cabinets they purchased.
794619_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	The Company s competitors participated vigorously in these promotional activities and the Company chose to meet these competitive offerings.
794619_11_ITEM7_P7_S3	Price-conscious consumers responded favorably to these promotional offerings and the Company and its large remodeling customers realized increased sales order volumes.
794619_11_ITEM7_P7_S4	The Company s remodeling sales rose more than 20% in the second half of fiscal 2011 and rose in the low teens for the entire fiscal year.
794619_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company also realized a mid single digit increase in its new construction sales during fiscal 2011, despite the 5% decline in housing starts.
794619_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	Management believes this result, combined with the Company s increase in remodeling sales, indicates that the Company realized market share gains in both of its sales channels during fiscal 2011.
794619_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	In the face of these difficult market conditions, the Company s net sales, gross profit, net loss and free cash flow all improved during fiscal 2011.
794619_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	Net sales grew by 11%, gross margin grew by 8%, net loss was reduced by 10% and free cash flow (defined as cash from operating activities less cash used for investing activities) improved by nearly $18 million.
794619_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Despite the present housing market downturn, the Company believes that the long-term fundamentals for the American housing industry continue to remain positive, based upon favorable population growth, favorable demographics, job creation and low long-term interest rates.
794619_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	Based upon this belief, the Company has continued to invest in improving its operations and its capabilities to service its customers.
794619_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	The Company remains focused on growing its market share and has continued to invest in developing and launching new products and expanding its marketing reach to new customers.
794619_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	During fiscal 2009, the Company announced cost reduction initiatives, including a salaried reduction-in-force, closure of two of its oldest manufacturing plants and suspension of operations in a third plant.
794619_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	These initiatives were completed during the first quarter of fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	of the restructuring charges related to these actions were reflected in the Company s results for fiscal 2009 and fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	Gross margin for fiscal 2011 was 11.7%, down from 12.0% in fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	The slight reduction in the Company s gross margin rate was driven by increased sales promotion costs.
794619_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	These promotions consisted of free products and cash payments to the Company s large remodeling customers based upon the amount and/or type of cabinets purchased.
794619_11_ITEM7_P13_S3	The Company s competitors participated vigorously in these promotional activities and the Company chose to maintain competitive parity by participating as well.
794619_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	The Company regularly assesses its long-lived assets to determine if any impairment has occurred and regularly evaluates its deferred tax assets to determine whether a valuation allowance is necessary.
794619_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	Although the Company is presently operating at a loss in what appears to be the bottom of the housing market, the Company expects that improvements in market demand and continued market share gains will enable it to return to profitability well before the expiration of the useful lives of its long-lived assets and any applicable tax carryforward periods.
794619_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	Accordingly, the Company has concluded that neither its long-lived assets pertaining to its 11 manufacturing plants nor any of its other long-lived assets were impaired and that no valuation allowance on its deferred tax assets was necessary as of April 30, 2011.
794619_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Restructuring charges recorded in connection with the Company s cost reduction initiatives aggregated $(0.0) million net of tax in fiscal 2011, $(1.7) million net of tax in fiscal 2010 and $(6.0) million net of tax in fiscal 2009.
794619_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	Exclusive of these charges, the Company generated a net loss of $(20.0) million in fiscal 2011, $(20.6) million in fiscal 2010 and net income of $2.8 million in fiscal 2009.
794619_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Net sales were $452.6 million in fiscal 2011, an increase of $46.0 million, or 11%, compared with fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	Overall unit volume for fiscal 2011 was 8% higher than in fiscal 2010, driven primarily by the Company s increased market share.
794619_11_ITEM7_P16_S2	Average revenue per unit increased 3% in fiscal 2011, driven primarily by shifts in product mix.
794619_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2010 decreased 26% to $406.5 million from $545.9 million in fiscal 2009.
794619_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	Overall unit volume for fiscal 2010 was 23% lower than in fiscal 2009, driven primarily by weaker remodeling sales volume.
794619_11_ITEM7_P17_S2	Average revenue per unit decreased 3% during fiscal 2010, driven primarily by an increased proportion of new construction sales within the Company s sales mix.
794619_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	Gross profit as a percentage of sales decreased to 11.7% in fiscal 2011 as compared with 12.0% in fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	increased sales promotion costs, diesel fuel and material costs.
794619_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	Specific changes and additional information included:
794619_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	Sales promotion costs increased in order to meet competitors promotional offerings to drive sales growth in a challenging market.
794619_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	Most of the sales promotions involved the use of free products or cash reimbursements back to the Company s large retail customers and were deducted from gross margin as opposed to being classified as operating expenses.
794619_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	Labor and overhead costs decreased by 3.0% as a percentage of net sales compared with the prior fiscal year, as increased sales volume caused increased productivity of direct labor and absorption of fixed overhead costs.
794619_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	During fiscal 2010, the Company s gross profit declined as a percentage of net sales from 16.4% to 12.0%.
794619_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	The impact of reduced sales volume in fiscal 2010 created inefficiencies from unabsorbed manufacturing overhead and in labor productivity, which more than offset the beneficial impact of reduced overhead costs related to plant closures, reduction in diesel fuel and material costs and the impact of a $1.3 million insurance recovery.
794619_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	Specific changes and additional information included:
794619_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	Labor and overhead costs increased by 5.2% as a percentage of net sales compared with the prior fiscal year, as the 23% decline in sales volume caused reduced productivity of direct labor and under-absorption of fixed overhead costs that more than offset the $17.9 million reduction in overhead driven by the Company s restructuring initiatives.
794619_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Selling and marketing expenses in fiscal 2011 were 13.5% of net sales, compared with 14.0% of net sales in fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	The decreased cost as a percent of sales in fiscal 2011 resulted from increased sales levels, which resulted in favorable leverage.
794619_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	Selling and marketing expenses were 14.0% of net sales in fiscal 2010 compared with 11.0% in fiscal 2009.
794619_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	The higher cost as a percent of sales in fiscal 2010 was driven by a 26% reduction in net sales that exceeded the reduction in spending as volume-based reductions in compensation costs were offset in part by increased promotional costs and increased business development activities compared with the prior year.
794619_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	General and administrative expenses for fiscal 2011 declined by $3.7 million, or 14%, compared with fiscal 2010 and represented 5.0% of net sales, compared with 6.5% of net sales for fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	The majority of the decline was related to a reduction in the Company s pay-for-performance variable compensation and reduced bad debt and related costs pertaining to insolvent customers.
794619_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	As of April 30, 2011, the Company had receivables from customers with a higher perceived level of risk aggregating less than $0.1 million.
794619_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	General and administrative expenses in fiscal 2010 declined by $0.4 million, or 2%, compared with fiscal 2009 and represented 6.5% of net sales, as compared with 4.9% of net sales for fiscal 2009.
794619_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	Declines associated with the Company s pay-for-performance variable compensation program and reduced bad debt expense were partially offset by the absence of a prior fiscal year gain of $0.6 million on the termination of a retiree health care plan.
794619_11_ITEM7_P27_S2	As of April 30, 2010, the Company had receivables from customers with a higher perceived level of risk aggregating $0.1 million.
794619_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	The Company generated a pre-tax loss of $30.0 million during fiscal 2011.
794619_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	Based upon statutory tax rates in effect and the impact of permanent tax differences for meals and entertainment, a tax basis adjustment and other permanent differences, the Company s effective tax rate was 33.2%.
794619_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	The Company s effective tax rate for fiscal 2010 was 39.7%, reflecting the impact of statutory tax rates in effect during the years to which the pre-tax loss was carried back, combined with permanent tax differences for general business credits and the domestic production deduction.
794619_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	The Company follows several indices, including but not limited to housing starts, existing home sales, mortgage interest rates, new jobs growth, GDP growth and consumer confidence that it believes are near-term leading indicators of overall demand for kitchen and bath cabinetry.
794619_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	The Company believes that while these indicators collectively suggest the long-term economic outlook for housing is positive, the near-term outlook remains subdued.
794619_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	The Company expects that the economic recovery will continue at roughly its current pace and that new job creation will average approximately 200,000 per month during its fiscal 2012.
794619_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	This in turn should translate into a gradual improvement in consumer confidence and enable the remodeling market to be roughly neutral to slightly positive compared with prior year levels, as the benefits from increased employment continue to be hampered by uncertain home prices and credit availability.
794619_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	The Company believes momentum from improving employment will result in improvement in new household formation from its recent low levels.
794619_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	This in turn should help improve housing starts by approximately 10%, to a range of 600,000 to 625,000 during fiscal 2012.
794619_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	The Company expects that it will maintain the market share gains it has made, enabling it to generate sales growth of approximately 5% to 8%.
794619_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	The Company plans to increase its capital expenditures from $8.5 million in fiscal 2011 to approximately $15 million in fiscal 2012, driven by increasing the number of sales display units deployed with customers and deploying machinery and equipment to enable production volume to increase.
794619_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	The Company expects that its operating cash flow may decline, driven by a decline in the amount of expected income tax refunds and increased working capital requirements as the Company s sales grow.
794619_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	The Company also expects it will experience inflationary pressures in lumber, plywood and various other materials that could negatively impact profitability during fiscal 2012.

794619_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	Management has chosen accounting policies that are necessary to give reasonable assurance that the Company s operational results and financial position are accurately and fairly reported.
794619_11_ITEM7_P58_S1	The significant accounting policies of the Company are disclosed in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
794619_11_ITEM7_P58_S2	The following discussion addresses the accounting policies that management believes have the greatest potential impact on the presentation of the financial condition and operating results of the Company for the periods being reported and that require the most judgment.
794619_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	Management regularly reviews these critical accounting policies and estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
794619_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the related carrying amounts may not be recoverable.
794619_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	For purposes of assessing if impairment exists, assets are grouped at the lowest level for which there are identifiable cash flows that are largely independent of the cash flows of other groups of assets.
794619_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	To determine whether an impairment has occurred, the Company compares estimates of the future undiscounted net cash flows of groups of assets to their carrying values.
794619_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	The Company has not recognized impairments of long-lived assets in the last three years.
794619_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company utilizes signed sales agreements that provide for transfer of title to the customer upon delivery.
794619_11_ITEM7_P61_S1	The Company must estimate the amount of sales that have been transferred to third-party carriers but not delivered to customers.
794619_11_ITEM7_P61_S2	The estimate is calculated using a lag factor determined by analyzing the actual difference between shipment date and delivery date of orders over the past 12 months.
794619_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	Revenue is only recognized on those shipments which the Company believes have been delivered to the customer.
794619_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company recognizes revenue based on the invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions as required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
794619_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	Collection is reasonably assured as determined through an analysis of accounts receivable data, including historical product returns and the evaluation of each customer s ability to pay.
794619_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	Allowances for sales returns are based on the historical relationship between shipments and returns.
794619_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company believes that its historical experience is an accurate reflection of future returns.
794619_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	The Company is self-insured for certain costs related to employee medical coverage and workers compensation liability.
794619_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	The Company maintains stop-loss coverage with third-party insurers to limit total exposure.
794619_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	The Company establishes a liability at the balance sheet date based on estimates for a variety of factors that influence the Company s ultimate cost.
794619_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	In the event that actual experience is substantially different from the estimates, the financial results for the period could be adversely affected.
794619_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	The Company believes that the methodologies used to estimate all factors related to employee medical coverage and workers compensation are an accurate reflection of the liability as of the date of the balance sheet.
794619_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company has two non-contributory defined benefit pension plans covering substantially all of the Company s employees.
794619_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	The estimated cost, benefits and pension obligation of these plans are determined using various assumptions.
794619_11_ITEM7_P68_S1	The most significant assumptions are the long-term expected rate of return on plan assets, the discount rate used to determine the present value of the pension obligations and the future rate of compensation level increases.
794619_11_ITEM7_P68_S2	In fiscal 2011, the Company determined the discount rate by referencing the Hewitt Above Median Yield Curve.
794619_11_ITEM7_P68_S3	Previously, the Company referred to the AON Yield Curve in establishing the discount rate.
794619_11_ITEM7_P68_S4	The Company believes that using a yield curve approach more accurately reflects changes in the present value of liabilities over time since each cash flow is discounted at the rate at which it could effectively be settled.
794619_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	The long-term expected rate of return on plan assets reflects the current mix of the plan assets invested in equities and bonds.
794619_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	The future rate of compensation levels reflects expected compensation trends.
794619_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	The following is a summary of the potential impact of a hypothetical 1% change in actuarial assumptions for the discount rate, rate of compensation, expected return on plan assets and consumer price index:
794619_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	Pension expense for fiscal 2011 and the assumptions used in that calculation are presented in Note H of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
794619_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	At April 30, 2011, the discount rate was 5.66% compared to 5.91% at April 30, 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P72_S1	The expected return on plan assets is 8.0%, which is consistent with fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P72_S2	The assumed rate of increase in compensation levels is 4.0% for the fiscal year ended April 30, 2011, unchanged from the prior fiscal year.
794619_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	The performance of the Company s pension plans is largely dependent on the assumptions used to measure the obligations of the plans and to estimate future performance of the plans invested assets.
794619_11_ITEM7_P73_S1	Over the past two measurement periods, the most material deviations between results based on assumptions and the actual plan performance have been as a result of the changes to the discount rate used to measure the plans benefit obligations and the actual return on plan assets.
794619_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	Under accounting guidelines, the discount rate is to be set to market at each annual measurement date.
794619_11_ITEM7_P74_S1	From the fiscal 2009 to fiscal 2010 measurement dates, the discount rate decreased from 7.16% to 5.91%, which was the primary driver in an actuarial loss of $21.3 million.
794619_11_ITEM7_P74_S2	From the fiscal 2010 to fiscal 2011 measurement dates, the discount rate decreased from 5.91% to 5.66%, which was the primary driver in the actuarial loss of $4.5 million.
794619_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	The Company strives to balance expected long-term returns and short-term volatility of pension plan assets.
794619_11_ITEM7_P75_S1	Favorable and unfavorable differences between the assumed and actual returns on plan assets are generally amortized over a period no longer than the average future working lifetime of the plans active participants.
794619_11_ITEM7_P75_S2	The actual rates of return on plan assets realized, net of investment manager fees were 11.9%, 21.5% and (16.8)% for fiscal years 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
794619_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	The fair value of plan assets at April 30, 2011 was $83.3 million compared to $78.4 million at April 30, 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P76_S1	The Company s projected benefit obligation exceeded plan assets by $36.7 million in fiscal 2011 and $29.1 million in fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P76_S2	The Company s $7.7 million increase in its net under-funded position during fiscal 2011 was driven by the Company s $4.5 million actuarial losses due to the decrease in the discount rate used and a $4.7 million loss due to additional benefits accruing, offset in part by a higher actual return on plan assets than expected.
794619_11_ITEM7_P76_S3	The Company expects its pension expense to increase from $6.9 million in fiscal 2011 to $7.4 million in fiscal 2012, due primarily to a further decrease in the discount rate offset by a higher return on plan assets than expected.
794619_11_ITEM7_P76_S4	The Company expects to contribute $2.9 million to its pension plans in fiscal 2012, which represents both required and discretionary funding.
794619_11_ITEM7_P76_S5	Under the requirements of the Pension Protection Act of 2006, the Company was not required to make mandatory contributions to its pension plans in either fiscal 2011 or in fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	The Company invests in promotional displays in retail stores to demonstrate product features, product specifications, quality specifications and serve as a training tool for designers.
794619_11_ITEM7_P77_S1	The investment is carried at cost less applicable amortization.
794619_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	Amortization is provided by the straight-line method on an individual display basis over the estimated period of economic benefit, approximately 30 to 36 months.
794619_11_ITEM7_P78_S1	The Company believes that the estimated period of economic benefit provides an accurate reflection of the value of displays as of the date of the balance sheet based on historical experience.
794619_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	The Company estimates outstanding warranty costs based on the historical relationship between warranty claims and revenues.
794619_11_ITEM7_P79_S1	The warranty accrual is reviewed monthly to verify that it properly reflects the Company s remaining obligation based on anticipated expenditures over the balance of the obligation period.
794619_11_ITEM7_P79_S2	Adjustments are made when actual warranty claim experience differs from estimates.
794619_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	Warranty claims are generally made within three months of the original shipment date.
794619_11_ITEM7_P81_S0	The calculation of stock-based compensation expense involves estimates that require management s judgment.
794619_11_ITEM7_P81_S1	These estimates include the fair value of each stock option and restricted stock unit award granted.
794619_11_ITEM7_P82_S0	Stock option awards are estimated on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
794619_11_ITEM7_P82_S1	There are two significant inputs into the Black-Scholes option pricing model: expected volatility and expected term.
794619_11_ITEM7_P82_S2	The Company estimates expected volatility based on the historical volatility of the Company s stock over a term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_11_ITEM7_P82_S3	The expected term of stock option awards granted is derived from historical exercise experience under the Company s stock option plans and represents the period of time that stock option awards granted are expected to be outstanding.
794619_11_ITEM7_P83_S0	For performance-based restricted stock units, the Company estimates the number of shares that will be granted upon satisfaction of the performance conditions, based upon actual and expected future operating results.
794619_11_ITEM7_P83_S1	The assumptions used in calculating the fair value of stock-based payment awards represent management s best estimates, but these estimates involve inherent uncertainties and the application of significant management judgment.
794619_11_ITEM7_P83_S2	As a result, if factors change or the Company uses different assumptions, stock-based compensation expense could be materially different in the future.
794619_11_ITEM7_P83_S3	In addition, the Company is required to estimate the expected forfeiture rate and only recognize expense for those shares expected to vest.
794619_11_ITEM7_P83_S4	If the Company s actual forfeiture rate is materially different from its estimate, the stock-based compensation expense could be significantly different from what the Company has recorded in the current period.
794619_11_ITEM7_P83_S5	See Note G to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion on stock-based compensation.
794619_11_ITEM7_P84_S0	Valuation of Deferred Tax Assets .
794619_11_ITEM7_P84_S1	The Company considers the need for a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets.
794619_11_ITEM7_P84_S2	The Company performed an analysis at April 30, 2011 and 2010 and determined in each case that a valuation allowance was not required.
794619_11_ITEM7_P84_S3	The Company considered all available evidence, both positive and negative, in determining the need for a valuation allowance.
794619_11_ITEM7_P84_S4	Based upon this analysis, including a consideration of recent losses, management determined that it is more likely than not that the Company s deferred tax assets will be realized through expected future income and the reversal of taxable temporary differences.
794619_11_ITEM7_P84_S5	The Company will continue to update this analysis on a periodic basis and changes in expectations about future income or the timing of the reversal of taxable temporary differences could cause the Company to record a valuation allowance in a future period.

794619_11_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Company manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_11_ITEM8_P0_S1	The Company's products are sold across the United States through a network of independent dealers and distributors and directly to home centers and major builders.
794619_11_ITEM8_P1_S0	The following is a description of the Company s significant accounting policies:
794619_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	Principles of Consolidation and Basis of Presentation:
794619_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly-owned subsidiary.
794619_11_ITEM8_P3_S1	Significant inter-company accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
794619_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	The Company recognizes revenue when product is delivered to the customer and title has passed.
794619_11_ITEM8_P4_S1	Revenue is based on invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions.
794619_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	Cost of Sales and Distribution : Cost of sales and distribution includes all costs associated with the manufacture and distribution of the Company s products including the costs of shipping and handling.
794619_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	Advertising Costs : Advertising costs are expensed as incurred.
794619_11_ITEM8_P6_S1	Advertising expenses for fiscal years 2011, 2010 and 2009 were $30.0 million, $16.0 million and $15.1 million, respectively.
794619_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents : Cash in excess of operating requirements is invested in money market accounts which are carried at cost (which approximates fair value).
794619_11_ITEM8_P7_S1	The Company considers all highly liquid short-term investments with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
794619_11_ITEM8_P7_S2	Cash equivalents were $46.8 million and $17.7 million at April 30, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
794619_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	Inventories : Inventories are stated at lower of cost or market.
794619_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	Inventory costs are determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method.
794619_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	The LIFO cost reserve is determined in the aggregate for inventory and is applied as a reduction to inventories determined on the first-in, first-out method (FIFO).
794619_11_ITEM8_P10_S1	FIFO inventory cost approximates replacement cost.
794619_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment: Property, plant and equipment is stated on the basis of cost less accumulated depreciation.
794619_11_ITEM8_P11_S1	Depreciation is provided by the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, which range from 15 to 30 years for buildings and improvements and 3 to 10 years for machinery and equipment.
794619_11_ITEM8_P11_S2	Assets under capital leases are amortized over the shorter of their estimated useful lives or the term of the related lease.
794619_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets: The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
794619_11_ITEM8_P12_S1	During fiscal years 2011, 2010 and 2009, the Company concluded no impairment existed.
794619_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	Promotional Displays : The Company invests in promotional displays in retail stores to demonstrate product features, product specifications, quality specifications and serve as a training tool for retail kitchen designers.
794619_11_ITEM8_P13_S1	The Company invests in these long-lived productive assets to provide the aforementioned benefits.
794619_11_ITEM8_P13_S2	The Company's investment in promotional displays is carried at cost less applicable amortization.
794619_11_ITEM8_P13_S3	Amortization is provided by the straight-line method on an individual display basis over periods of 30 to 36 months (the estimated period of benefit).
794619_11_ITEM8_P13_S4	Promotional display amortization expense for fiscal years 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $7.9 million, $9.8 million and $11.7 million, respectively, and is included in selling and marketing expenses.
794619_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	Income Taxes: The Company accounts for deferred income taxes utilizing the asset and liability method, whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized based on the tax effects of temporary differences between the financial statement amounts and the tax basis of assets and liabilities, using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which these items are expected to reverse.
794619_11_ITEM8_P14_S1	At each reporting date, the Company evaluates the need for a valuation allowance to reduce deferred tax assets to an amount that more likely than not will be realized.
794619_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	covering substantially all of the Company s employees.
794619_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	The Company recognizes the overfunded or underfunded status of its defined benefit pension plans, measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation, in its consolidated balance sheets.
794619_11_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Company also recognizes the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs, credits and transition costs as a component of other comprehensive income (loss), net of tax.

794619_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	For purposes of valuing stock option grants, the Company has identified two employee groups and one non-employee director group, based upon observed option exercise patterns.
794619_11_ITEM8_P41_S1	The Company uses the Black-Scholes option-pricing model to value the Company s stock options for each of the three groups.
794619_11_ITEM8_P41_S2	Using this option-pricing model, the fair value of each stock option award is estimated on the date of grant.
794619_11_ITEM8_P41_S3	The fair value of the Company s stock option awards is expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the stock options.
794619_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	The expected volatility assumption is based on the historical volatility of the Company s stock over a term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_11_ITEM8_P42_S1	The expected term of stock option awards granted is derived from the Company s historical exercise experience and represents the period of time that stock option awards granted are expected to be outstanding for each of the three identified groups.
794619_11_ITEM8_P42_S2	The expected term assumption incorporates the contractual term of an option grant, which is generally ten years for employees and from four years to ten years for non-employee directors, as well as the vesting period of an award, which is typically three years.
794619_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury constant maturity with a remaining term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	For purposes of determining the fair value of RSUs, the Company uses the closing stock price of its common stock as reported on the NASDAQ Global Select Market on the date of grant, reduced by the discounted value of future expected dividend payments during the vesting period, since the recipients are not entitled to dividends during the vesting period.
794619_11_ITEM8_P44_S1	The fair value of the Company s RSU awards is expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the RSUs to the extent the Company believes it is probable the related performance criteria, if any, will be met.
794619_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury constant maturity with a remaining term equal to the vesting period of the RSU grant.

794619_11_ITEM8_P87_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims, and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_11_ITEM8_P87_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_11_ITEM8_P88_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_11_ITEM8_P88_S1	The Company accounts for these loss contingencies in accordance with ASC 450.
794619_11_ITEM8_P89_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_11_ITEM8_P89_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible or remote, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_11_ITEM8_P89_S2	Where no loss estimate range can be made, the Company and its counsel perform a worst-case estimate.
794619_11_ITEM8_P89_S3	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_11_ITEM8_P90_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible were not material as of April 30, 2011.

794619_11_ITEM8_P108_S0	In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2009, the Company announced a restructuring plan to close two of its manufacturing plants, located in Berryville, Virginia and Moorefield, West Virginia and suspend operations in a third manufacturing plant located in Tahlequah, Oklahoma.
794619_11_ITEM8_P108_S1	These actions were completed during the first quarter of fiscal 2010.
794619_11_ITEM8_P108_S2	This initiative impacted approximately 600 employees.
794619_11_ITEM8_P108_S3	The continued housing slump, at that time, led to the decision to reduce production capacity.
794619_11_ITEM8_P108_S4	These initiatives were intended to increase the Company s utilization rates and decrease overhead costs within the Company s manufacturing operations.
794619_11_ITEM8_P108_S5	In addition to these initiatives, the Company made other staffing reductions during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2009.
794619_11_ITEM8_P109_S0	During fiscal years 2011, 2010 and 2009, the Company recognized pre-tax restructuring charges of $62,000, $2.8 million and $9.7 million, respectively.
794619_11_ITEM8_P109_S1	The Company recognized recurring operating costs for the closed facilities of $0.9 million in fiscal 2011.
794619_11_ITEM8_P109_S2	These costs will continue until the remaining closed plant is sold and the new plan for the suspended plant is determined.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S0	Of the three manufacturing plants idled in 2009, one of the closed plants has been sold and one is classified as held for sale and included in Other Assets on the Company s balance sheet at April 30, 2011.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S1	The Company believes that the $0.4 million net book value of this plant is fully recoverable.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S2	During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011, the Company sold its closed plant located in Berryville, Virginia and recognized a $0.9 million gain on the sale.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S3	The gain was recorded as Other Income.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S4	The Company has not yet determined how its idled manufacturing plant in Tahlequah, Oklahoma will be utilized in the future.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S5	Accordingly, the $4.6 million net book value for this asset continues to be classified as Property, Plant and Equipment on the Company s balance sheet at April 30, 2011 and continues to be depreciated at a rate of $0.5 million per year.
794619_11_ITEM8_P110_S6	The Company expects it may incur approximately $1.5 million in additional restructuring charges relating to management s estimate of shortfall in fair value of the idled Tahlequah plant for which future utilization plans have not been determined.

794619_11_ITEM8_P121_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
794619_11_ITEM8_P122_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
794619_11_ITEM8_P122_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
794619_11_ITEM8_P122_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
794619_11_ITEM8_P122_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
794619_11_ITEM8_P122_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
794619_11_ITEM8_P123_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
794619_11_ITEM8_P123_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
794619_11_ITEM8_P124_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
794619_11_ITEM8_P124_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
794619_11_ITEM8_P125_S0	In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of April 30, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

794619_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	American Woodmark Corporation ( American Woodmark or the Company ) manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	American Woodmark was incorporated in 1980 by the four principal managers of the Boise Cascade Cabinet Division through a leveraged buyout of that division.
794619_12_ITEM1_P0_S2	American Woodmark was operated privately until 1986 when it became a public company through a registered public offering of its common stock.
794619_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	American Woodmark currently offers framed stock cabinets in approximately 550 different cabinet lines, ranging in price from relatively inexpensive to medium-priced styles.
794619_12_ITEM1_P1_S1	Styles vary by design and color from natural wood finishes to low-pressure laminate surfaces.
794619_12_ITEM1_P1_S2	The product offering of stock cabinets includes 86 door designs in 18 colors.
794619_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	Stock cabinets consist of a common box with standard interior components and a maple, oak, cherry, or hickory front frame, door and/or drawer front.
794619_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	Products are primarily sold under the brand names of American Woodmark , Timberlake , Shenandoah Cabinetry , Potomac , and Waypoint Living Spaces .
794619_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	American Woodmark s products are sold on a national basis across the United States to the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_12_ITEM1_P4_S1	The Company services these markets through three primary channels: home centers, builders, and independent dealers and distributors.
794619_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company provides complete turnkey installation services to its direct builder customers via its network of nine service centers that are strategically located throughout the United States.
794619_12_ITEM1_P5_S1	The Company distributes its products to each market channel directly from four assembly plants through a third party logistics network.
794619_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	The primary raw materials used include hard maple, oak, cherry, soft maple, and hickory lumber and plywood.
794619_12_ITEM1_P6_S1	Additional raw materials include paint, particleboard, manufactured components, and hardware.
794619_12_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company currently purchases paint from one supplier; however, other sources are available.
794619_12_ITEM1_P6_S3	Other raw materials are purchased from more than one source and are readily available.
794619_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	American Woodmark operates in a highly fragmented industry that is composed of several thousand local, regional, and national manufacturers.
794619_12_ITEM1_P7_S1	The Company s principal means for competition is its breadth and variety of product offering, expanded service capabilities, geographic reach and affordable quality.
794619_12_ITEM1_P7_S2	The Company believes it is one of the three largest manufacturers of kitchen cabinets in the United States.
794619_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company s business has historically been subject to seasonal influences, with higher sales typically realized in the second and fourth fiscal quarters.
794619_12_ITEM1_P8_S1	General economic forces and changes in the Company s customer mix have reduced seasonal fluctuations in revenue over the past few years.
794619_12_ITEM1_P8_S2	The Company does not consider its level of order backlog to be material.
794619_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	In recognition of the cyclicality of the housing industry, the Company s policy is to operate with a minimal amount of financial leverage.
794619_12_ITEM1_P9_S1	The Company regularly maintains a debt to capital ratio of well below 20%, and working capital exclusive of cash of less than 6% of net sales.
794619_12_ITEM1_P9_S2	At April 30, 2012, debt to capital was 15.5%, and working capital net of cash was 1.0% of net sales.
794619_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	During the last fiscal year, American Woodmark had two primary customers, The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc., which together accounted for approximately 68% of the Company s sales in its fiscal year ended April 30, 2012 (fiscal 2012).
794619_12_ITEM1_P10_S1	The loss of either customer would have a material adverse effect on the Company.
794619_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	As of May 31, 2012, the Company had 3,791 employees.
794619_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	Less than 1% of the Company s employees are represented by labor unions.
794619_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes that its employee relations are good.
794619_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	American Woodmark s annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, proxy statements, and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge on the Company s web site at www.americanwoodmark.com as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
794619_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	The contents of the Company s web site are not, however, part of this report.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	There are a number of business risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These risks and uncertainties could cause future results to differ from past performance or expected results, including results described in statements elsewhere in this report that constitute "forward-looking statements" under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to the Company or currently believed to be immaterial also may adversely impact the business.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Should any risks or uncertainties develop into actual events, these developments could have material adverse effects on the Company s business, financial condition, and results of operations.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition are discussed elsewhere in this report, including in Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations under the headings Forward-Looking Statements, Market Risks, and Outlook for Fiscal 2013.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The Company s business is dependent upon remodeling activity and residential construction.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The Company s results of operations are affected by levels of home improvement and residential construction activity, including repair and remodeling and new construction.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Job creation levels, interest rates, availability of credit, energy costs, consumer confidence, national and regional economic conditions, and weather conditions and natural disasters can significantly impact levels of home improvement and residential construction activity.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Prolonged economic downturns may adversely impact the Company s sales, earnings and liquidity.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Through fiscal year 2012, the Company s sales levels have fallen 38% from their peak levels in 2006.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The Company s industry historically has been cyclical in nature and has fluctuated with economic cycles, including the current housing downturn.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	During economic downturns, the Company s industry could experience longer periods of recession and greater declines than the general economy.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The Company believes that its industry is significantly influenced by economic conditions generally and particularly by housing activity, consumer confidence, the level of personal discretionary spending, demographics and credit availability.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P3_S3	These factors not only may affect the ultimate consumer of the Company s products, but also may impact home centers, builders and the Company s other primary customers.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P3_S4	As a result, a continuation or worsening of current conditions could adversely affect the Company s sales and earnings as well as its cash flow and liquidity.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Company s future financial performance depends in part on the success of its new product development and other growth strategies.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The Company has increased its emphasis on new product development in recent years and continues to focus solely on organic growth.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Consequently, the Company s financial performance will, in part, reflect its success in implementing its growth strategies in its existing markets and in introducing new products.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The loss of, or a reduction in business from, either of the Company s key customers would have a material adverse effect upon its business.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The size and importance to the Company of its two largest customers is significant.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	These customers could make significant changes in their volume of purchases and could otherwise significantly affect the terms and conditions on which the Company does business.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Sales to The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc. were approximately 68% of total company sales for fiscal 2012.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Although builders, dealers, and other retailers represent other channels of distribution for the Company's products, an unplanned loss of a substantial portion of sales to The Home Depot or Lowe s Companies, Inc. would have a material adverse impact on the Company.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Manufacturing realignments and cost savings programs similar to the Company s 2012 Restructuring Plan could result in a decrease in the Company s near-term earnings and liquidity.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The Company continually reviews its manufacturing operations.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	These reviews could result in manufacturing realignments and cost savings programs, such as the consolidation and integration of facilities, functions, systems, or procedures, which in turn could result in a charge that would decrease near-term earnings and liquidity until the expected cost reductions are achieved.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Any such realignments would likely result in significant costs including, among others, severance, impairment, exit, and disposal costs and capital expenditures.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Impairment charges could reduce the Company s profitability.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The Company has significant long-lived assets, including deferred tax assets, recorded on its balance sheets.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If operating results decline or if the Company decides to restructure results as it did with the 2012 Restructuring Plan, the Company could incur impairment charges, which could have a material impact on its financial results.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of the carrying amount of its long-lived assets on an ongoing basis.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The outcome of future reviews could result in substantial impairment charges.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Impairment assessments inherently involve judgments as to assumptions about market conditions and the Company s ability to generate future cash flows and profitability, given those assumptions.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Future events and changing market conditions may impact the Company s assumptions as to prices, costs or other factors that may result in changes in the Company s estimates.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Although the Company believes the assumptions used in testing for impairment are reasonable, significant changes in these assumptions could produce a significantly different result.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The Company s operating results are affected by the cost and availability of raw materials.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Because the Company is dependent on outside suppliers for raw material needs, it must obtain sufficient quantities of quality raw materials from its suppliers at acceptable prices and in a timely manner.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P13_S2	The Company has no long-term supply contracts with its key suppliers.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P13_S3	A substantial decrease in the availability of products from the Company s suppliers, the loss of key supplier arrangements, or a substantial increase in the cost of its raw materials could adversely impact the Company s results of operations.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The Company may not be able to maintain or raise the prices of its products in response to inflation and increasing costs.
794619_12_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Short-term market and competitive pressures may prohibit the Company from raising prices to offset inflationary raw material and freight costs, which would adversely impact profit margins.

794619_12_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_12_ITEM3_P0_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_12_ITEM3_P1_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_12_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company accounts for these loss contingencies in accordance with ASC 450.
794619_12_ITEM3_P2_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_12_ITEM3_P2_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible or remote, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_12_ITEM3_P2_S2	Where no loss estimate range can be made, the Company and its counsel perform a worst-case estimate.
794619_12_ITEM3_P2_S3	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_12_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of estimated loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible was not material as of April 30, 2012.
794619_12_ITEM3_P4_S0	Also see the information under Legal Matters under Note K Commitments and Contingencies to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report under Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
