794619_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	American Woodmark Corporation ( American Woodmark or the Company ) manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	American Woodmark was incorporated in 1980 by the four principal managers of the Boise Cascade Cabinet Division through a leveraged buyout of that division.
794619_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	American Woodmark was operated privately until 1986 when it became a public company through a registered public offering of its common stock.
794619_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	American Woodmark currently offers framed stock cabinets in approximately 550 different cabinet lines, ranging in price from relatively inexpensive to medium-priced styles.
794619_13_ITEM1_P1_S1	Styles vary by design and color from natural wood finishes to low-pressure laminate surfaces.
794619_13_ITEM1_P1_S2	The product offering of stock cabinets includes 86 door designs in 18 colors.
794619_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	Stock cabinets consist of cabinet interiors of varying dimensions and construction options and a maple, oak, cherry, or hickory front frame, door and/or drawer front.
794619_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	Products are sold under the brand names of American Woodmark , Timberlake , Shenandoah Cabinetry , Potomac , and Waypoint Living Spaces .
794619_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	American Woodmark s products are sold on a national basis across the United States to the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	The Company services these markets through three primary channels: home centers, builders, and independent dealers and distributors.
794619_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company provides complete turnkey installation services to its direct builder customers via its network of nine service centers that are strategically located throughout the United States.
794619_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	The Company distributes its products to each market channel directly from four assembly plants through a third party logistics network.
794619_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	The primary raw materials used include hard maple, oak, cherry, soft maple, and hickory lumber and plywood.
794619_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	Additional raw materials include paint, particleboard, manufactured components, and hardware.
794619_13_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company currently purchases paint from one supplier; however, other sources are available.
794619_13_ITEM1_P6_S3	Other raw materials are purchased from more than one source and are readily available.
794619_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	American Woodmark operates in a highly fragmented industry that is composed of several thousand local, regional, and national manufacturers.
794619_13_ITEM1_P7_S1	The Company s principal means for competition is its breadth and variety of product offering, expanded service capabilities, geographic reach and affordable quality.
794619_13_ITEM1_P7_S2	The Company believes it is one of the three largest manufacturers of kitchen cabinets in the United States.
794619_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company s business has historically been subject to seasonal influences, with higher sales typically realized in the second and fourth fiscal quarters.
794619_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	General economic forces and changes in the Company s customer mix have reduced seasonal fluctuations in revenue over the past few years.
794619_13_ITEM1_P8_S2	The Company does not consider its level of order backlog to be material.
794619_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	In recognition of the cyclicality of the housing industry, the Company s policy is to operate with a minimal amount of financial leverage.
794619_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	The Company regularly maintains a debt to capital ratio of well below 20%, and working capital exclusive of cash of less than 6% of net sales.
794619_13_ITEM1_P9_S2	At April 30, 2013, debt to capital was 13.9%, and working capital net of cash was 1.9% of net sales.
794619_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	During the last fiscal year, American Woodmark had two primary customers, The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc., which together accounted for approximately 59% of the Company s sales in its fiscal year ended April 30, 2013 (fiscal 2013).
794619_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	The loss of either customer would have a material adverse effect on the Company.
794619_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	As of May 31, 2013, the Company had 4,537 employees.
794619_13_ITEM1_P11_S1	None of the Company s employees are represented by labor unions.
794619_13_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes that its employee relations are good.
794619_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	charge on the Company s web site at www.americanwoodmark.com as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
794619_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	The contents of the Company s web site are not, however, part of this report.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P0_S0	There are a number of business risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These risks and uncertainties could cause future results to differ from past performance or expected results, including results described in statements elsewhere in this report that constitute "forward-looking statements" under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to the Company or currently believed to be immaterial also may adversely impact the business.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Should any risks or uncertainties develop into actual events, these developments could have material adverse effects on the Company s business, financial condition, and results of operations.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition are discussed elsewhere in this report, including in Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations under the headings Forward-Looking Statements, Market Risks, and Outlook for Fiscal 2014.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The Company s business is dependent upon remodeling activity and residential construction.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The Company s results of operations are affected by levels of home improvement and residential construction activity, including repair and remodeling and new construction.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Job creation levels, interest rates, availability of credit, energy costs, consumer confidence, national and regional economic conditions, and weather conditions and natural disasters can significantly impact levels of home improvement and residential construction activity.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Prolonged economic downturns may adversely impact the Company s sales, earnings and liquidity.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Although they have recently rebounded, the Company s fiscal 2013 sales levels were 25% below their peak levels of 2006.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The Company s industry historically has been cyclical in nature and has fluctuated with economic cycles.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P3_S1	During economic downturns, the Company s industry could experience longer periods of recession and greater declines than the general economy.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The Company believes that its industry is significantly influenced by economic conditions generally and particularly by housing activity, consumer confidence, the level of personal discretionary spending, demographics and credit availability.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P3_S3	These factors not only may affect the ultimate consumer of the Company s products, but also may impact home centers, builders and the Company s other primary customers.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P3_S4	As a result, a worsening of current conditions could adversely affect the Company s sales and earnings as well as its cash flow and liquidity.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Company s future financial performance depends in part on the success of its new product development and other growth strategies.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The Company has increased its emphasis on new product development in recent years and continues to focus solely on organic growth.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Consequently, the Company s financial performance will, in part, reflect its success in implementing its growth strategies in its existing markets and in introducing new products.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The loss of, or a reduction in business from, either of the Company s key customers would have a material adverse effect upon its business.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The size and importance to the Company of its two largest customers is significant.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P6_S1	These customers could make significant changes in their volume of purchases and could otherwise significantly affect the terms and conditions on which the Company does business.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Sales to The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc. were approximately 59% of total company sales for fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Although builders, dealers, and other retailers represent other channels of distribution for the Company's products, an unplanned loss of a substantial portion of sales to The Home Depot or Lowe s Companies, Inc. would have a material adverse impact on the Company.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Manufacturing realignments and cost savings programs similar to the Company s 2012 Restructuring Plan could result in a decrease in the Company s near-term earnings and liquidity.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The Company continually reviews its manufacturing operations.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P8_S1	These reviews could result in manufacturing realignments and cost savings programs, such as the consolidation and integration of facilities, functions, systems, or procedures, which in turn could result in a charge that would decrease near-term earnings and liquidity until the expected cost reductions are achieved.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Any such realignments would likely result in significant costs including, among others, severance, impairment, exit, and disposal costs and capital expenditures.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Impairment charges could reduce the Company s profitability.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The Company has significant long-lived assets, including deferred tax assets, recorded on its balance sheets.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If operating results decline or if the Company decides to restructure results as it did with the 2012 Restructuring Plan, the Company could incur impairment charges, which could have a material impact on its financial results.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of the carrying amount of its long-lived assets on an ongoing basis.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The outcome of future reviews could result in substantial impairment charges.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Impairment assessments inherently involve judgments as to assumptions about market conditions and the Company s ability to generate future cash flows and profitability, given those assumptions.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Future events and changing market conditions may impact the Company s assumptions as to prices, costs or other factors that may result in changes in the Company s estimates.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Although the Company believes the assumptions used in testing for impairment are reasonable, significant changes in these assumptions could produce a significantly different result.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The Company s operating results are affected by the cost and availability of raw materials.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Because the Company is dependent on outside suppliers for raw material needs, it must obtain sufficient quantities of quality raw materials from its suppliers at acceptable prices and in a timely manner.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P13_S2	The Company has no long-term supply contracts with its key suppliers.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P13_S3	A substantial decrease in the availability of products from the Company s suppliers, the loss of key supplier arrangements, or a substantial increase in the cost of its raw materials could adversely impact the Company s results of operations.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The Company may not be able to maintain or raise the prices of its products in response to inflation and increasing costs.
794619_13_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Short-term market and competitive pressures may prohibit the Company from raising prices to offset inflationary raw material and freight costs, which would adversely impact profit margins.

794619_13_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_13_ITEM3_P0_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_13_ITEM3_P1_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_13_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company accounts for these loss contingencies in accordance with ASC 450.
794619_13_ITEM3_P2_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_13_ITEM3_P2_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible or remote, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_13_ITEM3_P2_S2	Where no loss estimate range can be made, the Company and its counsel perform a worst-case estimate.
794619_13_ITEM3_P2_S3	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_13_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of estimated loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible was not material as of April 30, 2013.
794619_13_ITEM3_P4_S0	Also see the information under Legal Matters under Note K Commitments and Contingencies to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report under Item 8, Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.

794619_13_ITEM7_P5_S0	American Woodmark Corporation manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P5_S1	Its products are sold on a national basis directly to home centers, major builders and home manufacturers and through a network of independent dealers and distributors.
794619_13_ITEM7_P5_S2	At April 30, 2013, the Company operated 9 manufacturing facilities and 9 service centers across the country.
794619_13_ITEM7_P6_S0	During the Company s fiscal year that ended on April 30, 2013 (fiscal 2013), the Company experienced improving housing market conditions for the first time since the housing market downturn that began in 2007.
794619_13_ITEM7_P7_S0	A number of positive factors evidenced the improving housing market, including:
794619_13_ITEM7_P8_S0	Cabinet sales, as reported by members of the Kitchen Cabinet Manufacturers Association (KCMA), increased by 11% during fiscal 2013, suggesting an increase in both new construction and remodeling sales of cabinets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P9_S0	Faced with an improving but still relatively subdued remodeling market, the Company s largest remodeling customers and competitors continued to utilize an elevated level of sales promotions in the Company s product category during fiscal 2013 to boost sales, although a noticeable easing occurred in the second half of fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P9_S1	The Company strives to maintain its promotional levels in line with market activity, with a goal of remaining competitive.
794619_13_ITEM7_P9_S2	The Company experienced promotional levels during fiscal 2013 that were lower than those experienced in its prior fiscal year.
794619_13_ITEM7_P9_S3	The Company s remodeling sales increased at a high-single digit pace during fiscal 2013 in a remodeling market that appears to have improved by a bit less than that level.
794619_13_ITEM7_P10_S0	The Company increased its net sales by 22% during fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P10_S1	The Company realized strong sales gains in its new construction channel during fiscal 2013, where sales increased by more than 40%, significantly outpacing the improvement in single-family housing starts.
794619_13_ITEM7_P11_S0	result, combined with the Company s increased remodeling sales, indicates the Company realized market share gains in both of its sales channels during fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P12_S0	During the third quarter of fiscal 2012, the Company announced several initiatives designed to reduce its cost base (the 2012 Restructuring), including the permanent closure of two manufacturing plants, the decision to sell a previously closed manufacturing facility, and the realignment of its retirement program, including the freezing of its pension plans.
794619_13_ITEM7_P12_S1	All of these initiatives were completed either prior to or just after the beginning of the Company s fiscal 2013, and restructuring charges related to these actions have been reflected in the Company s results during both years.
794619_13_ITEM7_P13_S0	Gross margin for fiscal 2013 was 16.3%, significantly improved from 12.9% in fiscal 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P13_S1	The increase in the Company s gross margin rate was driven by reductions in the labor and overhead costs associated with the Company s restructuring activities, the beneficial impact of increased sales volume and the absence of the prior year s inventory write down, which more than offset the impact of rising materials costs.
794619_13_ITEM7_P14_S0	The Company recorded restructuring charges of $15.9 million (pre-tax) and $10.0 million (after-tax) during fiscal 2012 and $1.4 million (pre-tax) and $0.9 million (after-tax) during fiscal 2013 in connection with these initiatives.
794619_13_ITEM7_P14_S1	Because the bulk of these restructuring efforts have been completed, the Company expects that its future out-of-pocket costs will be nominal.
794619_13_ITEM7_P14_S2	The Company sold a previously closed plant during fiscal 2013 and continues to include in Other Assets at an aggregate $2.7 million book value the other two plants held for sale that were included in the 2012 Restructuring.
794619_13_ITEM7_P15_S0	The Company regularly considers the need for a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P16_S0	The Company had a history of profitable operations for 16 consecutive years, from 1994 to 2009, followed by losses that coincided with the industry downturn from 2010 to 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P16_S1	As of April 30, 2013, the Company had total deferred tax assets of $38.7 million, down from $42.1 million at April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P16_S2	Growth in the Company s deferred tax assets in recent fiscal years resulted primarily from growth in its defined benefit pension liabilities and the impact of its recent losses prior to fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P16_S3	The Company earned sufficient net income during fiscal 2013 to fully utilize its Federal net operating loss carryforward.
794619_13_ITEM7_P16_S4	To fully realize these net deferred tax assets, the Company will need to, among other things, substantially reduce its net unfunded pension obligation of $53.7 million at April 30, 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P16_S5	The Company took definitive actions when it froze its pension plans as part of the 2012 Restructuring to enhance the probability that this objective is achieved in the future.
794619_13_ITEM7_P17_S0	The Company resumed the funding of its pension plans during fiscal year 2012, and expects to continue funding these plans for the foreseeable future, which will reduce both its unfunded pension plan obligation and its deferred tax asset.
794619_13_ITEM7_P17_S1	These actions, coupled with the recent improvement in the U.S. housing market and the Company s continued ability to grow its sales at a faster rate than its competitors, have enabled the Company to generate net income and reduce its deferred tax assets and unfunded pension obligation during fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P17_S2	The Company believes that the positive evidence of the housing industry improvement, coupled with the benefits from the Company s successful restructuring and continued market share gains have already driven a return to profitability that is expected to continue, and that the combined impact of these positive factors outweighs the negative factor of the Company s previous losses.
794619_13_ITEM7_P17_S3	Accordingly, Management has concluded it is more likely than not that the Company will realize its deferred tax assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P18_S0	The Company also regularly assesses its long-lived assets to determine if any impairment has occurred.
794619_13_ITEM7_P18_S1	The Company has concluded that none of the long-lived assets pertaining to its 9 manufacturing plants or any of its other long-lived assets were impaired as of April 30, 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P19_S0	Net sales were $630.4 million in fiscal 2013, an increase of $114.6 million, or 22%, compared with fiscal 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P19_S1	Overall unit volume for fiscal 2013 was 17% higher than in fiscal 2012, which management believes was driven primarily by the Company s increased market share.
794619_13_ITEM7_P19_S2	Average revenue per unit increased 4% in fiscal 2013, driven by improvements in the Company s product mix.
794619_13_ITEM7_P20_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2012 increased 14% to $515.8 million from $452.6 million in fiscal 2011.
794619_13_ITEM7_P20_S1	Overall unit volume for fiscal 2012 was 9% higher than in fiscal 2011, which management believes was driven primarily by the Company s increased market share.
794619_13_ITEM7_P20_S2	Average revenue per unit increased 5% during fiscal 2012, driven primarily by improvements in product mix.
794619_13_ITEM7_P21_S0	Gross profit as a percentage of sales increased to 16.3% in fiscal 2013 as compared with 12.9% in fiscal 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P21_S1	The improvement in gross profit margin was due primarily to the beneficial impact of higher sales volume and labor and overhead cost savings associated with the Company s two plant closures in April and May of 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P21_S2	This favorability was partially offset by an increase in material costs.
794619_13_ITEM7_P21_S3	Specific changes and additional information included:
794619_13_ITEM7_P22_S0	Sales promotion costs improved by 1.4% of net sales during fiscal 2013 compared with the prior year, as a result of both an increased proportion of new construction sales to the Company s total sales and reduced promotional activity.
794619_13_ITEM7_P22_S1	Sales promotions that involved the use of free products or cash reimbursements back to the Company s large remodeling customers were deducted from gross margin as opposed to being classified as operating expenses.
794619_13_ITEM7_P23_S0	During fiscal 2012, the Company s gross profit increased as a percentage of net sales to 12.9% from 11.7% in fiscal 2011.
794619_13_ITEM7_P23_S1	Increased sales volume in fiscal 2012 created improved labor efficiencies and more favorable absorption of manufacturing overhead costs, which were partially offset by increased sales promotion costs, material costs and diesel fuel.
794619_13_ITEM7_P23_S2	Specific changes and additional information included:
794619_13_ITEM7_P24_S0	Sales promotion costs increased by 0.7% of net sales during fiscal 2012, as the Company chose to remain competitive with competitors promotional offerings to drive sales growth in a challenging market.
794619_13_ITEM7_P25_S0	Selling and marketing expenses in fiscal 2013 were 9.1% of net sales, compared with 11.3% of net sales in fiscal 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P25_S1	Selling and marketing costs decreased by 1% despite a 22% increase in net sales.
794619_13_ITEM7_P25_S2	The improvement in sales and marketing costs in relation to net sales was due to reduced spending on product launch costs and cost reductions related to the Company s retirement plan changes, which were offset in part by increased sales compensation and staffing costs related to the Company s increased sales levels.
794619_13_ITEM7_P26_S0	Selling and marketing expenses were 11.3% of net sales in fiscal 2012 compared with 13.5% in fiscal 2011.
794619_13_ITEM7_P26_S1	Cost savings from lower marketing collateral and branding costs, as well as reductions in product display costs more than offset the increases in employee compensation and travel costs incurred by the Company in fiscal 2012.

794619_13_ITEM7_P30_S0	The Company tracks several metrics, including but not limited to housing starts, existing home sales, mortgage interest rates, new jobs growth, GDP growth and consumer confidence, which it believes are leading indicators of overall demand for kitchen and bath cabinetry.
794619_13_ITEM7_P30_S1	The Company believes that housing prices finally bottomed during its fiscal 2012 and have begun what it expects will be a multi-year improvement, driven by employment growth and a resumption of growth in new household formation.
794619_13_ITEM7_P30_S2	However, because the number of homeowners still owing more than what their homes are worth remains at historically high levels, the Company expects that while the cabinet remodeling market will show modest improvement it will continue to be well below the historic highs reached in the previous decade.
794619_13_ITEM7_P31_S0	Driven by an improving housing market, the Company expects that industry-wide cabinet remodeling sales will continue a trend that began during fiscal 2013 and improve at roughly a mid-single digit rate during its fiscal 2014.
794619_13_ITEM7_P32_S0	be relatively stable in fiscal 2014 and it will continue to gain market share in its growing dealer business.
794619_13_ITEM7_P32_S1	This combination is expected to result in remodeling sales growth that outpaces the market by several percentage points.
794619_13_ITEM7_P33_S0	The Company agrees with the consensus estimate that new construction starts will continue to grow at a mid-20% rate during its fiscal 2014.
794619_13_ITEM7_P33_S1	The Company s new construction sales growth outperformed the new construction market by approximately 20 points during fiscal 2013, and expects that it will again outperform the new construction market during fiscal 2014 but by a significantly lesser rate, as its comparable prior year sales levels become more challenging.
794619_13_ITEM7_P34_S0	Inclusive of the potential for modest sales mix and pricing improvements, the Company expects that it will grow its total sales at a mid-teen rate in fiscal 2014.
794619_13_ITEM7_P35_S0	The Company experienced production inefficiencies during the first half of its fiscal 2013 driven by the combination of work transition issues from its closed plants, coupled with production volume increases that were driven by unexpectedly high sales levels.
794619_13_ITEM7_P35_S1	These issues were resolved during the third quarter of the Company s fiscal 2013, enabling the Company s gross margin rate to improve in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P35_S2	The Company expects that its gross margin rate and net income for fiscal 2014 will improve compared with its fiscal 2013 performance.

794619_13_ITEM7_P65_S0	Management has chosen accounting policies that are necessary to give reasonable assurance that the Company s operational results and financial position are accurately and fairly reported.
794619_13_ITEM7_P65_S1	The significant accounting policies of the Company are disclosed in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this annual report.
794619_13_ITEM7_P65_S2	The following discussion addresses the accounting policies that management believes have the greatest potential impact on the presentation of the financial condition and operating results of the Company for the periods being reported and that require the most judgment.
794619_13_ITEM7_P66_S0	Management regularly reviews these critical accounting policies and estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
794619_13_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the related carrying amounts may not be recoverable.
794619_13_ITEM7_P67_S1	For purposes of assessing if impairment exists, assets are grouped at the lowest level for which there are identifiable cash flows that are largely independent of the cash flows of other groups of assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P67_S2	To determine whether an impairment has occurred, the Company compares estimates of the future undiscounted net cash flows of groups of assets to their carrying values.
794619_13_ITEM7_P67_S3	The Company has not recognized impairments of long-lived assets in the last three years other than the impairments related to restructuring activities.
794619_13_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Company utilizes signed sales agreements that provide for transfer of title to the customer upon delivery.
794619_13_ITEM7_P68_S1	The Company must estimate the amount of sales that have been transferred to third-party carriers but not delivered to customers.
794619_13_ITEM7_P68_S2	The estimate is calculated using a lag factor determined by analyzing the actual difference between shipment date and delivery date of orders over the past 12 months.
794619_13_ITEM7_P69_S0	Revenue is only recognized on those shipments which the Company believes have been delivered to the customer.
794619_13_ITEM7_P70_S0	The Company recognizes revenue based on the invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions as required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
794619_13_ITEM7_P70_S1	Collection is reasonably assured as determined through an analysis of accounts receivable data, including historical product returns and the evaluation of each customer s ability to pay.
794619_13_ITEM7_P71_S0	Allowances for sales returns are based on the historical relationship between shipments and returns.
794619_13_ITEM7_P71_S1	The Company believes that its historical experience is an accurate reflection of future returns.
794619_13_ITEM7_P72_S0	The Company is self-insured for certain costs related to employee medical coverage and workers compensation liability.
794619_13_ITEM7_P72_S1	The Company maintains stop-loss coverage with third-party insurers to limit total exposure.
794619_13_ITEM7_P73_S0	The Company establishes a liability at each balance sheet date based on estimates for a variety of factors that influence the Company s ultimate cost.
794619_13_ITEM7_P73_S1	In the event that actual experience is substantially different from the estimates, the financial results for the period could be adversely affected.
794619_13_ITEM7_P73_S2	The Company believes that the methodologies used to estimate all factors related to employee medical coverage and workers compensation are an accurate reflection of the liability as of the date of the balance sheet.
794619_13_ITEM7_P74_S0	The Company has two non-contributory defined benefit pension plans covering many of the Company s employees hired prior to April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P75_S0	Effective April 30, 2012, the Company froze all future benefit accruals under the Company s hourly and salary defined benefit pension plans.
794619_13_ITEM7_P76_S0	The estimated expense, benefits and pension obligations of these plans are determined using various assumptions.
794619_13_ITEM7_P76_S1	The most significant assumptions are the long-term expected rate of return on plan assets and the discount rate used to determine the present value of the pension obligations.
794619_13_ITEM7_P76_S2	In fiscal 2013 and 2012, the Company determined the discount rate by referencing the Aon Hewitt AA Bond Universe Yield Curve.
794619_13_ITEM7_P76_S3	In fiscal 2011, the Company referred to the Hewitt Above Median Yield Curve in establishing the discount rate.
794619_13_ITEM7_P76_S4	This change was caused by the merger of Aon and Hewitt and the corresponding elimination of the Hewitt Above Median Yield Curve.
794619_13_ITEM7_P77_S0	The Company believes that using a yield curve approach accurately reflects changes in the present value of liabilities over time since each cash flow is discounted at the rate at which it could effectively be settled.
794619_13_ITEM7_P78_S0	The long-term expected rate of return on plan assets reflects the current mix of the plan assets invested in equities and bonds.
794619_13_ITEM7_P79_S0	The following is a summary of the potential impact of a hypothetical 1% change in actuarial assumptions for the discount rate, expected return on plan assets and consumer price index:
794619_13_ITEM7_P80_S0	Pension expense for fiscal 2013 and the assumptions used in that calculation are presented in Note H of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
794619_13_ITEM7_P81_S0	At April 30, 2013, the discount rate was 4.21% compared with 4.66% at April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P81_S1	The expected return on plan assets was 7.5% at both April 30, 2013, and April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P81_S2	The assumed rate of increase in compensation levels was 4.0% for the fiscal years ended April 30, 2012 and 2011.
794619_13_ITEM7_P81_S3	The rate of compensation increase is not applicable for periods beyond April 30, 2012 because the Company froze its pension plans as of that date.
794619_13_ITEM7_P82_S0	The projected performance of the Company s pension plans is largely dependent on the assumptions used to measure the obligations of the plans and to estimate future performance of the plans invested assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P82_S1	Over the past two measurement periods, the most material deviations between results based on assumptions and the actual plan performance have resulted from changes to the discount rate used to measure the plans benefit obligations and the actual return on plan assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P83_S0	Accounting guidelines require the discount rate to be set to market at each annual measurement date.
794619_13_ITEM7_P83_S1	From the fiscal 2011 to fiscal 2012 measurement dates, the discount rate decreased from 5.66% at April 30, 2011 to 4.66% at April 30, 2012, which caused an actuarial loss of $26.3 million.
794619_13_ITEM7_P83_S2	From the fiscal 2012 to fiscal 2013 measurement dates, the discount rate decreased from 4.66% to 4.21% which caused an actuarial loss of $10.8 million.
794619_13_ITEM7_P84_S0	The Company strives to balance expected long-term returns and short-term volatility of pension plan assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P84_S1	Favorable and unfavorable differences between the assumed and actual returns on plan assets are generally amortized over a period no longer than the average life expectancy of the plans active participants.
794619_13_ITEM7_P84_S2	The actual rates of return on plan assets realized, net of investment manager fees, were 10.2%, 3.1% and 11.9% for fiscal 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
794619_13_ITEM7_P85_S0	The fair value of plan assets at April 30, 2013 was $95.7 million compared with $85.7 million at April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P85_S1	The Company s projected benefit obligation exceeded plan assets by $53.7 million in fiscal 2013 and by $50.5 million in fiscal 2012.
794619_13_ITEM7_P85_S2	The $3.2 million increase in the Company s net under-funded position during fiscal 2013 was primarily driven by the Company s $10.8 million actuarial losses, offset in part by a higher return on plan assets and Company contributions.
794619_13_ITEM7_P85_S3	The Company expects its pension expense to decrease from $0.6 million in fiscal 2013 to $0.2 million in fiscal 2014, due primarily to a higher expected return on plan assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P85_S4	The Company expects to contribute $2.3 million to its pension plans in fiscal 2014, which represents required funding.
794619_13_ITEM7_P85_S5	The Company made contributions of $4.9 million to its pension plans in fiscal 2013.
794619_13_ITEM7_P86_S0	The Company invests in promotional displays in retail stores to demonstrate product features, product and quality specifications and serve as a training tool for designers.
794619_13_ITEM7_P86_S1	The investment is carried at cost less applicable amortization.
794619_13_ITEM7_P87_S0	Amortization is provided by the straight-line method on an individual display basis over the estimated period of economic benefit, approximately 30 to 36 months.
794619_13_ITEM7_P87_S1	The Company believes that the estimated period of economic benefit provides an accurate reflection of the value of displays as of the date of the balance sheet based on historical experience.
794619_13_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Company estimates outstanding warranty costs based on the historical relationship between warranty claims and revenues.
794619_13_ITEM7_P88_S1	The warranty accrual is reviewed monthly to verify that it properly reflects the Company s remaining obligation based on anticipated expenditures over the balance of the obligation period.
794619_13_ITEM7_P88_S2	Adjustments are made when actual warranty claim experience differs from estimates.
794619_13_ITEM7_P89_S0	Warranty claims are generally made within two months of the original shipment date.
794619_13_ITEM7_P90_S0	The calculation of stock-based compensation expense involves estimates that require management s judgment.
794619_13_ITEM7_P90_S1	These estimates include the fair value of each stock option and restricted stock unit award granted.
794619_13_ITEM7_P91_S0	Stock option awards are estimated on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
794619_13_ITEM7_P91_S1	There are two significant inputs into the Black-Scholes option pricing model: expected volatility and expected term.
794619_13_ITEM7_P91_S2	The Company estimates expected volatility based on the historical volatility of the Company s stock over a term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_13_ITEM7_P91_S3	The expected term of stock option awards granted is derived from historical exercise experience under the Company s stock option plans and represents the period of time that stock option awards granted are expected to be outstanding.
794619_13_ITEM7_P92_S0	For performance-based restricted stock units, the Company estimates the number of shares that will be granted upon satisfaction of the performance conditions, based upon actual and expected future operating results.
794619_13_ITEM7_P92_S1	The assumptions used in calculating the fair value of stock-based payment awards represent management s best estimates, but these estimates involve inherent uncertainties and the application of significant management judgment.
794619_13_ITEM7_P92_S2	As a result, if factors change or the Company uses different assumptions, stock-based compensation expense could be materially different in the future.
794619_13_ITEM7_P92_S3	In addition, the Company is required to estimate the expected forfeiture rate and only recognize expense for those shares expected to vest.
794619_13_ITEM7_P92_S4	If the Company s actual forfeiture rate is materially different from its estimate, the stock-based compensation expense could be significantly different from what the Company has recorded in the current period.
794619_13_ITEM7_P92_S5	See Note G to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion on stock-based compensation.
794619_13_ITEM7_P93_S0	The Company regularly considers the need for a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets.
794619_13_ITEM7_P93_S1	Based upon the Company s analysis at April 30, 2013 and 2012, the Company determined in each case that a valuation allowance was not required.
794619_13_ITEM7_P93_S2	The Company considered all available evidence, both positive and negative, in determining the need for a valuation allowance.
794619_13_ITEM7_P93_S3	Based upon this analysis, management determined that it is more likely than not that the Company s deferred tax assets will be realized through expected future income and the reversal of taxable temporary differences.
794619_13_ITEM7_P93_S4	The Company will continue to update this analysis on a periodic basis and changes in expectations about future income or the timing of the reversal of taxable temporary differences could cause the Company to record a valuation allowance in a future period.
794619_13_ITEM7_P94_S0	In February 2013, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2013-02, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Reporting Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income, which requires an entity to provide information about the amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by component.
794619_13_ITEM7_P94_S1	In addition, an entity is required to present, either on the face of the statement where net income is presented or in the notes, significant amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by the respective line items of net income if the amount reclassified is required under U.S. GAAP to be reclassified to net income in its entirety in the same reporting period.

794619_13_ITEM7_P95_S1	The adoption of ASU 2013-02 is not expected to have a significant impact on the Company s results of operations or financial position.

794619_13_ITEM7_P96_S1	Additionally, ASU 2011-05 eliminates the option to present comprehensive income and its components as part of the statement of shareholders equity.
794619_13_ITEM7_P96_S2	The ASU does not change the items that must be reported in other comprehensive income.

794619_13_ITEM7_P97_S1	The amendments were made to allow FASB time to redeliberate whether to present on the face of the financial statements the effects of reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive income on the components of net income and other comprehensive income.

794619_13_ITEM8_P0_S0	The Company manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_13_ITEM8_P0_S1	The Company's products are sold across the United States through a network of independent dealers and distributors and directly to home centers and major builders.
794619_13_ITEM8_P1_S0	The following is a description of the Company s significant accounting policies:
794619_13_ITEM8_P2_S0	Principles of Consolidation and Basis of Presentation:
794619_13_ITEM8_P3_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly-owned subsidiary.
794619_13_ITEM8_P3_S1	Significant inter-company accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
794619_13_ITEM8_P4_S0	The Company recognizes revenue when product is delivered to the customer and title has passed.
794619_13_ITEM8_P4_S1	Revenue is based on invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions.
794619_13_ITEM8_P5_S0	Cost of Sales and Distribution : Cost of sales and distribution includes all costs associated with the manufacture and distribution of the Company s products including the costs of shipping and handling.
794619_13_ITEM8_P6_S0	Advertising Costs : Advertising costs are expensed as incurred.
794619_13_ITEM8_P6_S1	Advertising expenses for fiscal years 2013, 2012 and 2011 were $36.5 million, $37.4 million and $30.0 million, respectively.
794619_13_ITEM8_P7_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents : Cash in excess of operating requirements is invested in money market accounts which are carried at cost (which approximates fair value).
794619_13_ITEM8_P7_S1	The Company considers all highly liquid short-term investments with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
794619_13_ITEM8_P7_S2	Cash equivalents were $38.9 million and $31.8 million at April 30, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
794619_13_ITEM8_P8_S0	Inventories : Inventories are stated at lower of cost or market.
794619_13_ITEM8_P9_S0	Inventory costs are determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method.
794619_13_ITEM8_P10_S0	The LIFO cost reserve is determined in the aggregate for inventory and is applied as a reduction to inventories determined on the first-in, first-out method (FIFO).
794619_13_ITEM8_P10_S1	FIFO inventory cost approximates replacement cost.
794619_13_ITEM8_P11_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment: Property, plant and equipment is stated on the basis of cost less accumulated depreciation.
794619_13_ITEM8_P11_S1	Depreciation is provided by the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, which range from 15 to 30 years for buildings and improvements and 3 to 10 years for machinery and equipment.
794619_13_ITEM8_P11_S2	Assets under capital leases are amortized over the shorter of their estimated useful lives or the term of the related lease.
794619_13_ITEM8_P12_S0	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets: The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
794619_13_ITEM8_P12_S1	During fiscal years 2013, 2012 and 2011, the Company concluded no impairment existed, except for impairments related to restructuring activities.
794619_13_ITEM8_P13_S0	Promotional Displays : The Company invests in promotional displays in retail stores to demonstrate product features, product and quality specifications and serve as a training tool for retail kitchen designers.
794619_13_ITEM8_P13_S1	The Company invests in these long-lived productive assets to provide the aforementioned benefits.
794619_13_ITEM8_P13_S2	The Company's investment in promotional displays is carried at cost less applicable amortization.
794619_13_ITEM8_P13_S3	Amortization is provided by the straight-line method on an individual display basis over periods of 30 to 36 months (the estimated period of benefit).
794619_13_ITEM8_P13_S4	Promotional display amortization expense for fiscal years 2013, 2012 and 2011 was $4.0 million, $5.6 million and $7.9 million, respectively, and is included in selling and marketing expenses.
794619_13_ITEM8_P14_S0	Income Taxes: The Company accounts for deferred income taxes utilizing the asset and liability method, whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized based on the tax effects of temporary differences between the financial statement amounts and the tax basis of assets and liabilities, using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which these items are expected to reverse.
794619_13_ITEM8_P14_S1	At each reporting date, the Company evaluates the need for a valuation allowance to adjust deferred tax assets and liabilities to an amount that more likely than not will be realized.
794619_13_ITEM8_P15_S0	Pensions : The Company has two non-contributory defined benefit pension plans covering many of the Company s employees hired before April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM8_P15_S1	Both defined benefit pension plans were frozen effective April 30, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM8_P16_S0	The Company recognizes the overfunded or underfunded status of its defined benefit pension plans, measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation, in its consolidated balance sheets.
794619_13_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Company also recognizes the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs, credits and transition costs as a component of other comprehensive income (loss), net of tax.
794619_13_ITEM8_P17_S0	Stock-Based Compensation: The Company recognizes stock-based compensation expense based on the grant date fair value over the requisite service period.
794619_13_ITEM8_P18_S0	Recent Accounting Pronouncements : In February 2013, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2013-02, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Reporting Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income, which requires an entity to provide information about the amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by component.
794619_13_ITEM8_P18_S1	In addition, an entity is required to present, either on the face of the statement where net income is presented or in the notes, significant amounts reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by the respective line items of net income if the amount reclassified is required under U.S. GAAP to be reclassified to net income in its entirety in the same reporting period.
794619_13_ITEM8_P19_S0	The ASU does not change the current requirements for reporting net income or other comprehensive income in financial statements.
794619_13_ITEM8_P20_S0	The ASU is effective prospectively for fiscal years and interim periods within those years beginning after December 15, 2012.
794619_13_ITEM8_P20_S1	The adoption of ASU 2013-02 is not expected to have a significant impact on the Company s results of operations or financial position.
794619_13_ITEM8_P21_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-05, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Presentation of Comprehensive Income, which requires an entity to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income, or in two separate but consecutive statements.
794619_13_ITEM8_P21_S1	Additionally, ASU 2011-05 eliminates the option to present comprehensive income and its components as part of the statement of shareholders equity.
794619_13_ITEM8_P21_S2	The ASU does not change the items that must be reported in other comprehensive income.
794619_13_ITEM8_P21_S3	The Company adopted this guidance effective May 1, 2012 and now includes Statements of Comprehensive Income (Loss) in its financial statements.
794619_13_ITEM8_P22_S0	In December 2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-12, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Deferral of the Effective Date of Amendments to the Presentation of Reclassifications of Items Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income in ASU No. 2011-05.
794619_13_ITEM8_P22_S1	The amendments were made to allow FASB time to redeliberate whether to present on the face of the financial statements the effects of reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive income on the components of net income and other comprehensive income.
794619_13_ITEM8_P23_S0	Use of Estimates : The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during each reporting period.
794619_13_ITEM8_P23_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.

794619_13_ITEM8_P33_S0	The Company was in compliance with all covenants specified in the amended revolving credit facility as of April 30, 2013, as follows: (1) the Company s ratio of total liabilities to tangible net worth at April 30, 2013 was 1.0 to 1.0; (2) cash flow to fixed charges for its most recent four quarters was 2.72 to 1.0; and (3) its net income for the fiscal quarter ended April 30, 2013 was $5.2 million.

794619_13_ITEM8_P48_S0	For purposes of valuing stock option grants, the Company has identified two employee groups and one non-employee director group, based upon observed option exercise patterns.
794619_13_ITEM8_P48_S1	The Company uses the Black-Scholes option-pricing model to value the Company s stock options for each of the three groups.
794619_13_ITEM8_P48_S2	Using this option-pricing model, the fair value of each stock option award is estimated on the date of grant.
794619_13_ITEM8_P48_S3	The fair value of the Company s stock option awards is expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the stock options.
794619_13_ITEM8_P49_S0	The expected volatility assumption is based on the historical volatility of the Company s stock over a term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_13_ITEM8_P49_S1	The expected term of stock option awards granted is derived from the Company s historical exercise experience and represents the period of time that stock option awards granted are expected to be outstanding for each of the three identified groups.
794619_13_ITEM8_P49_S2	The expected term assumption incorporates the contractual term of an option grant, which is generally ten years for employees and from four to ten years for non-employee directors, as well as the vesting period of an award, which is typically three years.
794619_13_ITEM8_P50_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury constant maturity with a remaining term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_13_ITEM8_P51_S0	expected dividend payments during the vesting period, since the recipients are not entitled to dividends during the vesting period.

794619_13_ITEM8_P74_S0	Actuarial Assumptions : The discount rate at April 30 was used to measure the year-end benefit obligations and the earnings effects for the subsequent year.
794619_13_ITEM8_P74_S1	Actuarial assumptions used to determine benefit obligations and earnings effects for the pension plans follow:
794619_13_ITEM8_P75_S0	In fiscal 2013 and 2012, the Company determined the discount rate by referencing the Aon Hewitt AA Bond Universe Yield Curve.
794619_13_ITEM8_P75_S1	In fiscal 2011, the Company referred to the Hewitt Above Median Yield Curve in establishing the discount rate.
794619_13_ITEM8_P75_S2	This change was caused by the merger of Aon and Hewitt and the corresponding elimination of the Hewitt Above Median Yield Curve.
794619_13_ITEM8_P76_S0	The Company believes that using a yield curve approach accurately reflects changes in the present value of liabilities over time since each cash flow is discounted at the rate at which it could effectively be settled.
794619_13_ITEM8_P77_S0	In developing the expected long-term rate of return assumption for the assets of the defined benefit pension plans, the Company evaluated input from its third party pension plan asset managers, including their review of asset class return expectations and long-term inflation assumptions.
794619_13_ITEM8_P77_S1	The Company also considered the related historical ten-year average asset returns at April 30, 2013.
794619_13_ITEM8_P78_S0	The Company amortizes experience gains and losses, as well as the effects of changes in actuarial assumptions and plan provisions, over the average remaining lifetime of the active participants.

794619_13_ITEM8_P96_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims, and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_13_ITEM8_P96_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_13_ITEM8_P97_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_13_ITEM8_P98_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_13_ITEM8_P98_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible or remote, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_13_ITEM8_P98_S2	Where no loss estimate range can be made, the Company and its counsel perform a worst-case estimate.
794619_13_ITEM8_P98_S3	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_13_ITEM8_P99_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible was not material as of April 30, 2013.
794619_13_ITEM8_P100_S0	The Company estimates outstanding warranty costs based on the historical relationship between warranty claims and revenues.
794619_13_ITEM8_P100_S1	The warranty accrual is reviewed monthly to verify that it properly reflects the remaining obligation based on the anticipated expenditures over the balance of the obligation period.
794619_13_ITEM8_P101_S0	warranty claim experience differs from estimates.
794619_13_ITEM8_P101_S1	Warranty claims are generally made within two months of the original shipment date.

794619_13_ITEM8_P133_S0	We have audited American Woodmark Corporation s internal control over financial reporting as of April 30, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework , issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
794619_13_ITEM8_P133_S1	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting .
794619_13_ITEM8_P133_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
794619_13_ITEM8_P134_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
794619_13_ITEM8_P134_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
794619_13_ITEM8_P134_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
794619_13_ITEM8_P134_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
794619_13_ITEM8_P134_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
794619_13_ITEM8_P135_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
794619_13_ITEM8_P135_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
794619_13_ITEM8_P136_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
794619_13_ITEM8_P136_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
794619_13_ITEM8_P137_S0	In our opinion, American Woodmark Corporation maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of April 30, 2013, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

794619_13_ITEM15_P18_S0	THIS SECOND AMENDMENT TO LOAN AGREEMENT (this Amendment ) is entered into as of this 23rd day of April, 2013, effective as of December 30, 2011, between the DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT , a principal department of the State of Maryland (the Department ), and AMERICAN WOODMARK CORPORATION , a Virginia corporation (the Borrower ).
794619_13_ITEM15_P19_S0	The Maryland Economic Development Corporation, a body politic and corporate and public instrumentality of the State of Maryland ( MEDCO ) made a conditional loan to the Borrower in the original principal amount of $1,484,320.00 (the Loan ) pursuant to the terms of a Loan Agreement dated as of February 9, 2005, between MEDCO and the Borrower (the Original Loan Agreement ), as amended by a First Amendment to Loan Agreement dated as of April 4, 2008, between the Department and the Borrower (as amended, the Loan Agreement ).
794619_13_ITEM15_P20_S0	The Loan is evidenced by a deed of trust note dated February 9, 2005, made by the Borrower payable to the order of MEDCO in the original principal amount of $1,484,320.00 (the Original Note ), as amended by a Deed of Trust Note Modification Agreement dated as of April 4, 2008, between the Borrower and the Department (as amended, the Note ), and as further amended by a Second Deed of Trust Note Modification Agreement dated the same date as this Amendment between the Borrower and the Department (the Note Modification ).
794619_13_ITEM15_P21_S0	MEDCO assigned all of its rights in the Original Note, Original Loan Agreement, and all other Financing Documents (as defined in the Original Loan Agreement) to the Department pursuant to an Assignment dated February 9, 2005, attached to the Original Note, and an Assignment of Loan Documents dated February 9, 2005, from MEDCO to the Department.
794619_13_ITEM15_P22_S0	The Borrower fell short by 10 Permanent, Full-time Employees of its goal to employ 300 Permanent, Full-time Employees on December 31, 2009 under the terms of the Loan Agreement as it existed prior to the date of this Amendment.
794619_13_ITEM15_P22_S1	The Borrower has repaid the Department $34,465.00 ($3000 for each of the 10 Permanent, Full-time Employees, plus accrued interest through December 31, 2009, at the per annum rate of 3% from the date of disbursement of the Loan proceeds) in satisfaction of the shortfall.
794619_13_ITEM15_P22_S2	This payment shall not affect the partial repayment calculations set forth in this Amendment.

794619_13_ITEM15_P70_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
794619_14_ITEM1_P0_S0	American Woodmark Corporation ( American Woodmark or the Company ) manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_14_ITEM1_P0_S1	American Woodmark was incorporated in 1980 by the four principal managers of the Boise Cascade Cabinet Division through a leveraged buyout of that division.
794619_14_ITEM1_P0_S2	American Woodmark was operated privately until 1986 when it became a public company through a registered public offering of its common stock.
794619_14_ITEM1_P1_S0	American Woodmark currently offers framed stock cabinets in approximately 600 different cabinet lines, ranging in price from relatively inexpensive to medium-priced styles.
794619_14_ITEM1_P1_S1	Styles vary by design and color from natural wood finishes to low-pressure laminate surfaces.
794619_14_ITEM1_P1_S2	The product offering of stock cabinets includes 85 door designs in 19 colors.
794619_14_ITEM1_P2_S0	Stock cabinets consist of cabinet interiors of varying dimensions and construction options and a maple, oak, cherry, or hickory front frame, door and/or drawer front.
794619_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	Products are sold under the brand names of American Woodmark , Timberlake , Shenandoah Cabinetry , Potomac , and Waypoint Living Spaces .
794619_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	American Woodmark s products are sold on a national basis across the United States to the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_14_ITEM1_P4_S1	The Company services these markets through three primary channels: home centers, builders, and independent dealers and distributors.
794619_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company provides complete turnkey installation services to its direct builder customers via its network of nine service centers that are strategically located throughout the United States.
794619_14_ITEM1_P5_S1	The Company distributes its products to each market channel directly from four assembly plants through a third party logistics network.
794619_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	The primary raw materials used include hard maple, oak, cherry, soft maple, and hickory lumber and plywood.
794619_14_ITEM1_P6_S1	Additional raw materials include paint, particleboard, manufactured components, and hardware.
794619_14_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company currently purchases paint from one supplier; however, other sources are available.
794619_14_ITEM1_P6_S3	Other raw materials are purchased from more than one source and are readily available.
794619_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	American Woodmark operates in a highly fragmented industry that is composed of several thousand local, regional, and national manufacturers.
794619_14_ITEM1_P7_S1	The Company s principal means for competition is its breadth and variety of product offering, expanded service capabilities, geographic reach and affordable quality.
794619_14_ITEM1_P7_S2	The Company believes it is one of the three largest manufacturers of kitchen cabinets in the United States.
794619_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Company s business has historically been subject to seasonal influences, with higher sales typically realized in the second and fourth fiscal quarters.
794619_14_ITEM1_P8_S1	General economic forces and changes in the Company s customer mix have reduced seasonal fluctuations in revenue over the past few years.
794619_14_ITEM1_P8_S2	The Company does not consider its level of order backlog to be material.
794619_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	In recognition of the cyclicality of the housing industry, the Company s policy is to operate with a minimal amount of financial leverage.
794619_14_ITEM1_P9_S1	The Company regularly maintains a debt to capital ratio of well below 20%, and working capital exclusive of cash of less than 6% of net sales.
794619_14_ITEM1_P9_S2	At April 30, 201 4 , debt to capital was 9.7 %, and working capital net of cash was 1. 8 % of net sales.
794619_14_ITEM1_P10_S0	During the last fiscal year, American Woodmark had two primary customers, The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc., which together accounted for approximately 4 9 % of the Company s sales in its fiscal year ended April 30, 201 4 (fiscal 201 4 ).
794619_14_ITEM1_P10_S1	The loss of either customer would have a material adverse effect on the Company.
794619_14_ITEM1_P11_S0	As of May 31, 201 4 , the Company had 4,9 1 6 employees.
794619_14_ITEM1_P11_S1	None of the Company s employees are represented by labor unions.
794619_14_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes that its employee relations are good.
794619_14_ITEM1_P12_S0	American Woodmark s annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, proxy statements, and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge on the Company s web site at www.americanwoodmark.com as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
794619_14_ITEM1_P12_S1	The contents of the Company s web site are not, however, part of this report.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P0_S0	There are a number of business risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These risks and uncertainties could cause future results to differ from past performance or expected results, including results described in statements elsewhere in this report that constitute "forward-looking statements" under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to the Company or currently believed to be immaterial also may adversely impact the Company s business.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Should any risks or uncertainties develop into actual events, these developments could have material adverse effects on the Company s business, financial condition, and results of operations.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition are discussed elsewhere in this report, including in Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations under the headings Forward-Looking Statements, Seasonality , and Outlook for Fiscal 201 5 .
794619_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The Company s business is dependent upon remodeling activity and residential construction.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The Company s results of operations are affected by levels of home improvement and residential construction activity, including repair and remodeling and new construction.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Job creation levels, interest rates, availability of credit, energy costs, consumer confidence, national and regional economic conditions, and weather conditions and natural disasters can significantly impact levels of home improvement and residential construction activity.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Prolonged economic downturns may adversely impact the Company s sales, earnings and liquidity.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Although they have recently rebounded , the Company s fiscal 201 4 sales levels were 13 % below their peak levels of 2006.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The Company s industry historically has been cyclical in nature and has fluctuated with economic cycles.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P3_S1	During economic downturns, the Company s industry could experience longer periods of recession and greater declines than the general economy.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The Company believes that its industry is significantly influenced by economic conditions generally and particularly by housing activity, consumer confidence, the level of personal discretionary spending, demographics and credit availability.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P3_S3	These factors not only may affect the ultimate consumer of the Company s products, but also may impact home centers, builders and the Company s other primary customers.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P3_S4	As a result, a worsening of economic conditions could adversely affect the Company s sales and earnings as well as its cash flow and liquidity.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Company s future financial performance depends in part on the success of its new product development and other growth strategies.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The Company has increased its emphasis on new product development in recent years and continues to focus solely on organic growth.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Consequently, the Company s financial performance will, in part, reflect its success in implementing its growth strategies in its existing markets and in introducing new products.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The loss of, or a reduction in business from, either of the Company s key customers would have a material adverse effect upon its business.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The size and importance to the Company of its two largest customers is significant.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P6_S1	These customers could make significant changes in their volume of purchases and could otherwise significantly affect the terms and conditions on which the Company does business.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Sales to The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc. were approximately 4 9 % of total company sales for fiscal 201 4 .
794619_14_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Although builders, dealers, and other retailers represent other channels of distribution for the Company's products, an unplanned loss of a substantial portion of sales to The Home Depot or Lowe s Companies, Inc. would have a material adverse impact on the Company.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Manufacturing expansion to add capacity could result in a decrease in the Company s near-term earnings.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The Company continually reviews its manufacturing operations.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P8_S1	These reviews could result in the expansion of capacity, functions, systems, or procedures, which in turn could result in inefficiencies for a period that would decrease near-term earnings until the additional capacity is in place and fully operating.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P8_S2	In addition, downturns in the economy could potentially have a larger impact on the Company as a result of this added capacity.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Impairment charges could reduce the Company s profitability.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The Company has significant long-lived assets, including deferred tax assets, recorded on its balance sheets.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If operating results decline or if the Company decides to restructure its operations as it did with the 2012 Restructuring Plan, the Company could incur impairment charges, which could have a material impact on its financial results.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of the carrying amount of its long-lived assets on an ongoing basis.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The outcome of future reviews could result in substantial impairment charges.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Future events and changing market conditions may impact the Company s assumptions as to prices, costs or other factors that may result in changes in the Company s estimates.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The Company s operating results are affected by the cost and availability of raw materials.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Because the Company is dependent on outside suppliers for raw material needs, it must obtain sufficient quantities of quality raw materials from its suppliers at acceptable prices and in a timely manner.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P13_S2	The Company has no long-term supply contracts with its key suppliers.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P13_S3	A substantial decrease in the availability of products from the Company s suppliers, the loss of key supplier arrangements, or a substantial increase in the cost of its raw materials could adversely impact the Company s results of operations.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The Company may not be able to maintain or raise the prices of its products in response to inflation and increasing costs.
794619_14_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Short-term market and competitive pressures may prohibit the Company from raising prices to offset inflationary raw material and freight costs, which would adversely impact profit margins.
794619_14_ITEM2_P0_S0	American Woodmark leases its Corporate Office located in Winchester, Virginia.
794619_14_ITEM2_P0_S1	In addition, the Company leases 1 manufacturing facility in Hardy County, West Virginia and owns 8 manufacturing facilities located primarily in the eastern United States.
794619_14_ITEM2_P0_S2	The Company also leases 9 primary service centers, 2 satellite service centers, and 3 additional office centers located throughout the United States that support the sale and distribution of products to each market channel.

794619_14_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_14_ITEM3_P0_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_14_ITEM3_P1_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_14_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company accounts for these loss contingencies in accordance with ASC 450.
794619_14_ITEM3_P2_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_14_ITEM3_P2_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_14_ITEM3_P2_S2	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_14_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of estimated loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible was not material as of April 30, 201 4 .
794619_14_ITEM3_P4_S0	Also see the information under Legal Matters under Note K Commitments and Contingencies to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report under Item 8 .
