794619_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	Management has chosen accounting policies that are necessary to give reasonable assurance that the Company s operational results and financial position are accurately and fairly reported.
794619_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	The significant accounting policies of the Company are disclosed in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this annual report.
794619_16_ITEM7_P56_S2	The following discussion addresses the accounting policies that management believes have the greatest potential impact on the presentation of the financial condition and operating results of the Company for the periods being reported and that require the most judgment.
794619_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	Management regularly reviews these critical accounting policies and estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
794619_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company utilizes signed sales agreements that provide for transfer of title to the customer upon delivery.
794619_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	The Company must estimate the amount of sales that have been transferred to third-party carriers but not delivered to customers.
794619_16_ITEM7_P58_S2	The estimate is calculated using a lag factor determined by analyzing the actual difference between shipment date and delivery date of orders over the past 12 months.
794619_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	Revenue is only recognized on those shipments which the Company believes have been delivered to the customer.
794619_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company recognizes revenue based on the invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions as required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
794619_16_ITEM7_P60_S1	Collection is reasonably assured as determined through an analysis of accounts receivable data, including historical product returns and the evaluation of each customer s ability to pay.
794619_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	Allowances for sales returns are based on the historical relationship between shipments and returns.
794619_16_ITEM7_P61_S1	The Company believes that its historical experience is an accurate reflection of future returns.
794619_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company is self-insured for certain costs related to employee medical coverage, workers compensation liability, general liability, auto liability and property insurance.
794619_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	The Company maintains stop-loss coverage with third-party insurers to limit total exposure.
794619_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company establishes a liability at each balance sheet date based on estimates for a variety of factors that influence the Company s ultimate cost.
794619_16_ITEM7_P63_S1	In the event that actual experience is substantially different from the estimates, the financial results for the period could be adversely affected.
794619_16_ITEM7_P63_S2	The Company believes that the methodologies used to estimate insurance liabilities are an accurate reflection of the liabilities as of the date of the balance sheet.
794619_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company has two non-contributory defined benefit pension plans covering many of the Company s employees hired prior to April 30, 2012.
794619_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	Effective April 30, 2012, the Company froze all future benefit accruals under the Company s hourly and salaried defined benefit pension plans.
794619_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	The estimated expense, benefits and pension obligations of these plans are determined using various assumptions.
794619_16_ITEM7_P66_S1	The most significant assumptions are the long-term expected rate of return on plan assets and the discount rate used to determine the present value of the pension obligations.
794619_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	The long-term expected rate of return on plan assets reflects the current mix of the plan assets invested in equities and bonds.
794619_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	Beginning with the April 30, 2016 measurement, the Company refined the method used to determine the service and interest cost components of its net periodic benefit cost.
794619_16_ITEM7_P68_S1	Previously, the cost was determined using a single weighted-average discount rate derived from the yield curve.
794619_16_ITEM7_P68_S2	Under the refined method, known as the spot rate approach, individual spot rates along the yield curve that correspond with the timing of each benefit payment will be used.
794619_16_ITEM7_P68_S3	The Company believes this change provides a more precise measurement of service and interest costs by improving the correlation between projected cash outflows and corresponding spot rates on the yield curve.
794619_16_ITEM7_P68_S4	Compared to the previous method, the spot rate approach will decrease the service and interest components of the benefit costs in fiscal 2017.
794619_16_ITEM7_P68_S5	There is no impact on the total benefit obligation.
794619_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	Pension expense for fiscal 2016 and the assumptions used in that calculation are presented in Note H of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
794619_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	At April 30, 2016, the discount rate was 4.06% compared with 4.19% at April 30, 2015.
794619_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	The expected return on plan assets was 7.5% at both April 30, 2016, and April 30, 2015.
794619_16_ITEM7_P70_S2	The rate of compensation increase is not applicable for periods beyond April 30, 2012 because the Company froze its pension plans as of that date.
794619_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	The projected performance of the Company s pension plans is largely dependent on the assumptions used to measure the obligations of the plans and to estimate future performance of the plans invested assets.
794619_16_ITEM7_P71_S1	Over the past two measurement periods, the most material deviations between results based on assumptions and the actual plan performance have resulted from changes to the discount rate used to measure the plans benefit obligations and the actual return on plan assets.
794619_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	Accounting guidelines require the discount rate to be set to a current market rate at each annual measurement date.
794619_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	From the fiscal 2014 to fiscal 2015 measurement dates, the discount rate decreased from 4.56% at April 30, 2014 to 4.19% at April 30, 2015, which caused an actuarial loss of $24.2 million.
794619_16_ITEM7_P72_S2	From the fiscal 2015 to fiscal 2016 measurement dates, the discount rate decreased from 4.19% to 4.06%, which caused an actuarial loss of $1.9 million.
794619_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	The Company strives to balance expected long-term returns and short-term volatility of pension plan assets.
794619_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	Favorable and unfavorable differences between the assumed and actual returns on plan assets are generally amortized over a period no longer than the average life expectancy of the plans active participants.
794619_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	The actual rates of return on plan assets realized, net of investment manager fees, were (1.6)%, 6.6% and 9.4% for fiscal 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
794619_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The fair value of plan assets at April 30, 2016 was $107.0 million compared with $108.7 million at April 30, 2015.
794619_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	The Company s projected benefit obligation exceeded plan assets by $67.1 million in fiscal 2016 and by $61.3 million in fiscal 2015.
794619_16_ITEM7_P74_S2	The $5.8 million increase in the Company s net under-funded position during fiscal 2016 was primarily driven by the Company s $1.9 million actuarial loss and asset returns that were less than expected, offset by increased Company contributions.
794619_16_ITEM7_P74_S3	The Company expects its pension expense to decrease from $0.3 million in fiscal 2016 to $(0.5) million in fiscal 2017, due primarily to the change to the new mortality tables, decrease in the discount rate and the spot rate approach.
794619_16_ITEM7_P74_S4	The Company expects to contribute $7.3 million to its pension plans in fiscal 2017, which represents required and discretionary funding.
794619_16_ITEM7_P74_S5	The Company made contributions of $5.0 million to its pension plans in fiscal 2016.
794619_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	The Company regularly considers the need for a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets.
794619_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance when, after considering all positive and negative evidence, it is determined that it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
794619_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	The Company has recorded a valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets for certain state investment tax credit (ITC) carryforwards.
794619_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance when, after considering all positive and negative evidence, it is determined that it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.

794619_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	The Company manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.

794619_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	The following is a description of the Company s significant accounting policies:
794619_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	Principles of Consolidation and Basis of Presentation:
794619_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly-owned subsidiary.
794619_16_ITEM8_P8_S1	Significant inter-company accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
794619_16_ITEM8_P9_S0	The Company recognizes revenue when product is delivered to the customer and title has passed.
794619_16_ITEM8_P9_S1	Revenue is based on invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions.
794619_16_ITEM8_P10_S0	Cost of Sales and Distribution : Cost of sales and distribution includes all costs associated with the manufacture and distribution of the Company s products including the costs of shipping and handling.
794619_16_ITEM8_P11_S0	Advertising Costs : Advertising costs are expensed as incurred.
794619_16_ITEM8_P11_S1	Advertising expenses for fiscal years 2016 , 2015 and 2014 were $38.1 million , $34.3 million and $30.4 million , respectively.
794619_16_ITEM8_P12_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents : Cash in excess of operating requirements is invested in money market accounts which are carried at cost (which approximates fair value).
794619_16_ITEM8_P12_S1	The Company considers all highly liquid short-term investments with an original maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
794619_16_ITEM8_P12_S2	Cash equivalents were $34.0 million and $33.0 million at April 30, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
794619_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	Investments in Certificates of Deposit: The Company invests excess cash in certificates of deposit which are carried at cost (which approximates fair value).
794619_16_ITEM8_P13_S1	Certificates of deposit with original maturities greater than three months and remaining maturities less than one year are classified as current assets.
794619_16_ITEM8_P13_S2	Certificates of deposit with remaining maturities greater than one year are classified as long-term assets.
794619_16_ITEM8_P14_S0	Inventories : Inventories are stated at lower of cost or market.
794619_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	Inventory costs are determined by the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method.
794619_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	The LIFO cost reserve is determined in the aggregate for inventory and is applied as a reduction to inventories determined on the first-in, first-out method (FIFO).
794619_16_ITEM8_P16_S1	FIFO inventory cost approximates replacement cost.
794619_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment: Property, plant and equipment is stated on the basis of cost less accumulated depreciation.
794619_16_ITEM8_P17_S1	Depreciation is provided by the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the related assets, which range from 15 to 30 years for buildings and improvements and 3 to 10 years for machinery and equipment.
794619_16_ITEM8_P17_S2	Assets under capital leases are amortized over the shorter of their estimated useful lives or the term of the related lease.
794619_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets: The Company reviews its long-lived assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
794619_16_ITEM8_P18_S1	During fiscal years 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , the Company concluded no impairment existed, except for impairments related to restructuring activities.
794619_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	Promotional Displays : The Company invests in promotional displays in retail stores to demonstrate product features, product and quality specifications and serve as a training tool for retail kitchen designers.
794619_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	The Company invests in these long-lived productive assets to provide the aforementioned benefits.
794619_16_ITEM8_P19_S2	The Company's investment in promotional displays is carried at cost less applicable amortization.
794619_16_ITEM8_P19_S3	Amortization is provided by the straight-line method on an individual display basis over periods of 30 to 36 months (the estimated period of benefit).
794619_16_ITEM8_P19_S4	Promotional display amortization expense for fiscal years 2016 , 2015 and 2014 was $3.4 million , $3.6 million and $3.7 million , respectively, and is included in selling and marketing expenses.
794619_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	Income Taxes: The Company accounts for deferred income taxes utilizing the asset and liability method, whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized based on the tax effects of temporary differences between the financial statement amounts and the tax basis of assets and liabilities, using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which these items are expected to reverse.
794619_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	At each reporting date, the Company evaluates the need for a valuation allowance to adjust deferred tax assets and liabilities to an amount that more likely than not will be realized.
794619_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	Pensions : The Company has two non-contributory defined benefit pension plans covering many of the Company s employees hired before April 30, 2012.
794619_16_ITEM8_P21_S1	Both defined benefit pension plans were frozen effective April 30, 2012.
794619_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	The Company recognizes the overfunded or underfunded status of its defined benefit pension plans, measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation, in its consolidated balance sheets.
794619_16_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Company also recognizes the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs, credits and transition costs as a component of other comprehensive income (loss), net of tax.
794619_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	Stock-Based Compensation: The Company recognizes stock-based compensation expense based on the grant date fair value over the requisite service period.
794619_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	The Company is self-insured for certain costs related to employee medical coverage, workers compensation liability, general liability, auto liability and property insurance.
794619_16_ITEM8_P24_S1	The Company maintains stop-loss coverage with third-party insurers to limit total exposure.
794619_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	The Company establishes a liability at each balance sheet date based on estimates for a variety of factors that influence the Company s ultimate cost.
794619_16_ITEM8_P25_S1	In the event that actual experience is substantially different from the estimates, the financial results for the period could be adversely affected.
794619_16_ITEM8_P25_S2	The Company believes that the methodologies used to estimate insurance liabilities are an accurate reflection of the liabilities as of the date of the balance sheet.

794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	On January 25, 2016 the Company entered into a New Markets Tax Credit ("NMTC") financing agreement, pursuant to section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and Kentucky Revised Statutes Sections 141.432 through 141.434, to take advantage of a tax credit related to working capital and capital improvements at its Monticello, Kentucky facility.
794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S1	This financing agreement was structured with unrelated third party financial institutions (the Investors), their wholly-owned investment funds ("Investment Funds") and their wholly-owned community development entities ("CDEs") in connection with our participation in qualified transactions under the NMTC program.
794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S2	In exchange for substantially all of the benefits derived from the tax credits, the Investors made a contribution of $2.3 million , net of syndication fees, to the project.
794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S3	Upon closing the transaction, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company provided a $4.3 million loan receivable to the Investment Funds, which is included in other long term assets in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S4	The Company also entered into loan agreements aggregating $6.6 million payable to the CDEs sponsoring the project.
794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S5	The loans have a term of thirty years with an aggregate interest rate of approximately 1.2% .
794619_16_ITEM8_P54_S6	As of April 30, 2016 the Company had drawn $3.2 million of the loan proceeds, which is included in long-term debt in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
794619_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	The NMTC is subject to recapture for a period of seven years, the compliance period.
794619_16_ITEM8_P55_S1	During the compliance period, the Company is required to comply with various regulations and contractual provisions that apply to the NMTC arrangement.
794619_16_ITEM8_P55_S2	We do not anticipate any credit recaptures will be required in connection with this arrangement.
794619_16_ITEM8_P55_S3	This transaction also includes a put/call feature which becomes enforceable at the end of the compliance period whereby we may be obligated or entitled to repurchase the Investors interest in the Investment Funds.
794619_16_ITEM8_P55_S4	The value attributable to the put/call is nominal.
794619_16_ITEM8_P55_S5	Direct costs of $0.3 million incurred in structuring the financing arrangement are deferred and will be recognized as expense over the term of the loans ( 30 years).

794619_16_ITEM8_P62_S0	For purposes of valuing stock option grants, the Company has identified one employee group and one non-employee director group, based upon observed option exercise patterns.
794619_16_ITEM8_P62_S1	The Company uses the Black-Scholes option-pricing model to value the Company s stock options for each of the groups.
794619_16_ITEM8_P62_S2	Using this option-pricing model, the fair value of each stock option award is estimated on the date of grant.
794619_16_ITEM8_P62_S3	The fair value of the Company s stock option awards is expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the stock options.
794619_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	The expected volatility assumption is based on the historical volatility of the Company s stock over a term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_16_ITEM8_P63_S1	The expected term of stock option awards granted is derived from the Company s historical exercise experience and represents the period of time that stock option awards granted are expected to be outstanding for each of the identified groups.
794619_16_ITEM8_P63_S2	The expected term assumption incorporates the contractual term of an option grant, which is generally ten years for employees and from four to ten years for non-employee directors, as well as the vesting period of an award, which is typically three years.
794619_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury constant maturity with a remaining term equal to the expected term of the option granted.
794619_16_ITEM8_P65_S0	For purposes of determining the fair value of RSUs, the Company uses the closing stock price of its common stock as reported on the NASDAQ Global Select Market on the date of grant.
794619_16_ITEM8_P65_S1	The fair value of the Company s RSU awards is expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the RSUs to the extent the Company believes it is probable the related performance criteria, if any, will be met.
794619_16_ITEM8_P66_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury constant maturity with a remaining term equal to the vesting period of the RSU grant.

794619_16_ITEM8_P90_S0	Actuarial Assumptions : The discount rate at April 30 was used to measure the year-end benefit obligations and the earnings effects for the subsequent year.
794619_16_ITEM8_P90_S1	Actuarial assumptions used to determine benefit obligations and earnings effects for the pension plans follow:
794619_16_ITEM8_P91_S0	The Company bases the discount rate on a current yield curve developed from a portfolio of high-quality fixed-income investments with maturities consistent with the projected benefit payout period.
794619_16_ITEM8_P91_S1	The long-term rate of return on assets is determined based on consideration of historical and forward-looking returns and the current and expected asset allocation strategy.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S0	Beginning with the April 30, 2016 measurement, the Company refined the method used to determine the service and interest cost components of its net periodic benefit cost.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S1	Previously, the cost was determined using a single weighted-average discount rate derived from the yield curve.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S2	Under the refined method, known as the spot rate approach, individual spot rates along the yield curve that correspond with the timing of each benefit payment will be used.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S3	The Company believes this change provides a more precise measurement of service and interest costs by improving the correlation between projected cash outflows and corresponding spot rates on the yield curve.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S4	Compared to the previous method, the spot rate approach will decrease the service and interest components of the benefit costs in fiscal 2017.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S5	There is no impact on the total benefit obligation.
794619_16_ITEM8_P92_S6	The Company will account for this change prospectively as a change in accounting estimate.
794619_16_ITEM8_P93_S0	In developing the expected long-term rate of return assumption for the assets of the defined benefit pension plans, the Company evaluated input from its third party pension plan asset managers, including their review of asset class return expectations and long-term inflation assumptions.
794619_16_ITEM8_P94_S0	The Company amortizes experience gains and losses, as well as the effects of changes in actuarial assumptions and plan provisions, over the average remaining lifetime of the active participants.

794619_16_ITEM8_P114_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including without limitation product liability and general liability claims, and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

794619_16_ITEM8_P115_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_16_ITEM8_P116_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_16_ITEM8_P116_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible, a range of loss estimates is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_16_ITEM8_P116_S2	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consultation with independent counsel.
794619_16_ITEM8_P117_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible is not material as of April 30, 2016.

794619_16_ITEM8_P147_S0	The Board of Directors and Shareholders of American Woodmark Corporation:
794619_16_ITEM8_P148_S0	We have audited American Woodmark Corporation s (the Company) internal control over financial reporting as of April 30, 2016, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) , issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
794619_16_ITEM8_P148_S1	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Annual Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting .
794619_16_ITEM8_P148_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
794619_16_ITEM8_P149_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
794619_16_ITEM8_P149_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
794619_16_ITEM8_P149_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
794619_16_ITEM8_P149_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
794619_16_ITEM8_P149_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
794619_16_ITEM8_P150_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
794619_16_ITEM8_P150_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
794619_16_ITEM8_P151_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
794619_16_ITEM8_P151_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
794619_16_ITEM8_P152_S0	In our opinion, American Woodmark Corporation maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of April 30, 2016, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

794619_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	American Woodmark Corporation ( American Woodmark or the Company ) manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	American Woodmark was incorporated in 1980 by the four principal managers of the Boise Cascade Cabinet Division through a leveraged buyout of that division.
794619_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	American Woodmark was operated privately until 1986 when it became a public company through a registered public offering of its common stock.
794619_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	American Woodmark currently offers framed stock cabinets in 514 different cabinet lines, ranging in price from relatively inexpensive to medium-priced styles.
794619_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our cabinets are offered in a broad range of sizes, contruction and decorative options to achieve a broad range of design layouts.
794619_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	To satisfy the fashion and style needs of the market place we offer 85 door designs with a targeted range of painted and stained finishes on maple, cherry and oak as well as engineered fronts under the Duraform TM mark.
794619_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	Products are sold under the brand names of American Woodmark , Simply Woodmark , Timberlake , Shenandoah Cabinetry , Shenandoah Value Series , and Waypoint Living Spaces .
794619_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	American Woodmark s products are sold on a national basis across the United States to the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_17_ITEM1_P3_S1	The Company services these markets through three primary channels: home centers, builders, and independent dealers and distributors.
794619_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company provides complete turnkey installation services to its direct builder customers via its network of seven service centers that are strategically located throughout the United States.
794619_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	The Company distributes its products to each market channel directly from four assembly plants through a third party logistics network.
794619_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	The primary raw materials used include hard maple, soft maple, oak, and cherry lumber and plywood.
794619_17_ITEM1_P5_S1	Additional raw materials include paint, particleboard, medium density fiberboard, high density fiberboard, manufactured components and hardware.
794619_17_ITEM1_P5_S2	The Company currently purchases paint from one supplier; however, other sources are available.
794619_17_ITEM1_P5_S3	Other raw materials are purchased from more than one source and are readily available.
794619_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	American Woodmark operates in a highly fragmented industry that is composed of several thousand local, regional, and national manufacturers.
794619_17_ITEM1_P6_S1	The Company s principal means for competition is its breadth and variety of product offerings, expanded service capabilities, geographic reach and affordable quality.
794619_17_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Company believes it is one of the three largest manufacturers of kitchen cabinets in the United States.
794619_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	The Company s business has historically been subject to seasonal influences, with higher sales typically realized in the second and fourth fiscal quarters.
794619_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	General economic forces and changes in the Company s customer mix have reduced seasonal fluctuations in revenue over the past few years.
794619_17_ITEM1_P7_S2	The Company does not consider its level of order backlog to be material.
794619_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	In recognition of the cyclicality of the housing industry, the Company s policy is to operate with a minimal amount of financial leverage.
794619_17_ITEM1_P8_S1	The Company regularly maintains a debt to capital ratio of well below 20%, and working capital net of cash of less than 6% of net sales.
794619_17_ITEM1_P8_S2	At April 30, 2017, debt to capital was 4.2%, and working capital net of cash was 5.9% of net sales.
794619_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	During the fiscal year ended April 30, 2017 ("fiscal 2017"), American Woodmark had two primary customers, The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc., which together accounted for approximately 37% of the Company s sales.
794619_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	The loss of either customer would have a material adverse effect on the Company.
794619_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	The Company holds patents, patent applications, licenses, trademarks, trade names, trade secrets and proprietary manufacturing processes.
794619_17_ITEM1_P10_S1	The Company views its trademarks and other intellectual property rights as important to its business.
794619_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	As of May 31, 2017, the Company had 5,808 employees.
794619_17_ITEM1_P11_S1	None of the Company s employees are represented by labor unions.
794619_17_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes that its employee relations are good.
794619_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	American Woodmark s annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, proxy statements, and all amendments to those reports are available free of charge on the Company s web site at www.americanwoodmark.com as soon as reasonably practicable after such material is electronically filed with, or furnished to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
794619_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	The contents of the Company s web site are not, however, part of, or incorporated by reference into, this report.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	There are a number of business risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These risks and uncertainties could cause future results to differ from past performance or expected results, including results described in statements elsewhere in this report that constitute "forward-looking statements" under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to the Company or currently believed to be immaterial also may adversely impact the Company s business.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Should any risks or uncertainties develop into actual events, these developments could have material adverse effects on the Company s business, financial condition, and results of operations.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the Company s business, results of operations and financial condition are discussed elsewhere in this report, including in Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations under the headings Forward-Looking Statements, Seasonality, and Outlook for Fiscal 2018.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The Company s business is dependent upon remodeling activity and residential construction.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The Company s results of operations are affected by levels of home improvement and residential construction activity, including repair and remodeling and new construction.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Job creation levels, interest rates, availability of credit, energy costs, consumer confidence, national and regional economic conditions, and weather conditions and natural disasters can significantly impact levels of home improvement and residential construction activity and therefore significantly impact the Company's operations.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Prolonged economic downturns may adversely impact the Company s sales, earnings and liquidity.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The Company s industry historically has been cyclical in nature and has fluctuated with economic cycles.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P3_S1	During economic downturns, the Company s industry could experience longer periods of recession and greater declines than the general economy.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P3_S2	The Company believes that its industry is significantly influenced by economic conditions generally and particularly by housing activity, consumer confidence, the level of personal discretionary spending, demographics and credit availability.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P3_S3	These factors not only may affect the ultimate consumer of the Company s products, but also may impact home centers, builders and the Company s other primary customers.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P3_S4	As a result, a worsening of economic conditions could adversely affect the Company s sales and earnings as well as its cash flow and liquidity.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	The Company s future financial performance depends in part on the success of its new product development and other growth strategies.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The Company has increased its emphasis on new product development in recent years and continues to focus on organic growth.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Consequently, the Company s financial performance will, in part, reflect its success in implementing its growth strategies in its existing markets and in introducing new products.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	The loss of, or a reduction in business from, either of the Company s key customers would have a material adverse effect upon its business.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The size and importance to the Company of its two largest customers are significant.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P6_S1	These customers could make significant changes in their volume of purchases and could otherwise significantly affect the terms and conditions on which the Company does business.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Sales to The Home Depot and Lowe s Companies, Inc. were approximately 37% of total company sales for fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Although builders, dealers and other retailers represent other channels of distribution for the Company's products, an unplanned loss of a substantial portion of sales to The Home Depot or Lowe s Companies, Inc. would have a material adverse impact on the Company.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P6_S4	A significant change in the terms and conditions on which the Company does business with The Home Depot or Lowe's Companies, Inc. could also have a material adverse impact on the Company.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Manufacturing expansion to add capacity could result in a decrease in the Company s near-term earnings.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The Company continually reviews its manufacturing operations.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P8_S1	These reviews could result in the expansion of capacity, functions, systems, or procedures, which in turn could result in inefficiencies for a period that would decrease near-term earnings until the additional capacity is in place and fully operating.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P8_S2	In addition, downturns in the economy could potentially have a larger impact on the Company as a result of this added capacity.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Impairment charges could reduce the Company s profitability.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The Company has significant long-lived assets, including deferred tax assets, recorded on its balance sheets.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P10_S1	If operating results decline or if the Company decides to restructure its operations, the Company could incur impairment charges, which could have a material impact on its financial results.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of the carrying amount of its long-lived assets on an ongoing basis.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The outcome of future reviews could result in substantial impairment charges.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Impairment assessments inherently involve judgments as to assumptions about market conditions and the Company s ability to generate future cash flows and profitability, given those assumptions.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Future events and changing market conditions may impact the Company s assumptions as to prices, costs or other factors that may result in changes in the Company s estimates.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The Company s operating results are affected by the cost and availability of raw materials.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Because the Company is dependent on outside suppliers for raw material needs, it must obtain sufficient quantities of quality raw materials from its suppliers at acceptable prices and in a timely manner.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P13_S2	The Company has no long-term supply contracts with its key suppliers.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P13_S3	A substantial decrease in the availability of products from the Company s suppliers, the loss of key supplier arrangements, or a substantial increase in the cost of its raw materials could adversely impact the Company s results of operations.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The Company may not be able to maintain or raise the prices of its products in response to inflation and increasing costs.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Short-term market and competitive pressures may prohibit the Company from raising prices to offset inflationary or otherwise increasing raw material and freight costs, which would adversely impact profit margins.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	The Company's operations may be adversely affected by information systems interruptions or intrusions.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P16_S0	The Company relies on a number of information technology systems to process, transmit, store and manage information to support its business activities.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Increased global cybersecurity vulnerabilities, threats and more sophisticated and targeted attacks pose a risk to its information technology systems.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The Company has established security policies, processes and layers of defense designed to help identify and protect against intentional and unintentional misappropriation or corruption of its systems and information and disruption of its operations.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Despite these efforts, systems may be damaged, disrupted, or shut down due to attacks by unauthorized access, malicious software, undetected intrusion, hardware failures, or other events, and in these circumstances the Company's disaster recovery planning may be ineffective or inadequate.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P17_S2	These breaches or intrusions could lead to business interruption, exposure of proprietary or confidential information, data corruption, damage to the Company's reputation, exposure to litigation and increased operational costs.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Such events could have a material adverse impact on the Company's business, financial condition and results of operation.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P17_S4	In addition, the Company could be adversely affected if any of its significant customers or suppliers experience any similar events that disrupt their business operations or damage their reputation.

794619_17_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Although the Company believes that its facilities and operations are in material compliance with such laws, ordinances and regulations, it could incur substantial costs, including legal expenses, as a result of noncompliance with, or liability for cleanup or other costs or damages under, such laws, ordinances and regulations.
794619_17_ITEM1A_P18_S3	As the owner and lessee of real property, the Company can be held liable for the investigation or remediation of contamination on such properties, in some circumstances, without regard to whether the Company knew of or was responsible for such contamination.

794619_17_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in suits and claims in the normal course of business, including, without limitation, product liability and general liability claims and claims pending before the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
794619_17_ITEM3_P0_S1	On at least a quarterly basis, the Company consults with its legal counsel to ascertain the reasonable likelihood that such claims may result in a loss.
794619_17_ITEM3_P1_S0	As required by ASC Topic 450, Contingencies (ASC 450), the Company categorizes the various suits and claims into three categories according to their likelihood for resulting in potential loss: those that are probable, those that are reasonably possible and those that are deemed to be remote.
794619_17_ITEM3_P1_S1	The Company accounts for these loss contingencies in accordance with ASC 450.
794619_17_ITEM3_P2_S0	Where losses are deemed to be probable and estimable, accruals are made.
794619_17_ITEM3_P2_S1	Where losses are deemed to be reasonably possible, a range of loss estimate is determined and considered for disclosure.
794619_17_ITEM3_P2_S2	In determining these loss range estimates, the Company considers known values of similar claims and consults with independent counsel.
794619_17_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company believes that the aggregate range of estimated loss stemming from the various suits and asserted and unasserted claims which were deemed to be either probable or reasonably possible was not material as of April 30, 2017.
794619_17_ITEM3_P4_S0	Also see the information under Legal Matters under Note K Commitments and Contingencies to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this report under Item 8.

794619_17_ITEM7_P7_S0	American Woodmark Corporation manufactures and distributes kitchen cabinets and vanities for the remodeling and new home construction markets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P7_S1	Its products are sold on a national basis directly to home centers, major builders and home manufacturers and through a network of independent dealers and distributors.
794619_17_ITEM7_P7_S2	At April 30, 2017, the Company operated 9 manufacturing facilities and 7 service centers across the country.
794619_17_ITEM7_P8_S0	During the Company s fiscal year that ended on April 30, 2017 ("fiscal 2017"), the Company continued to experience improving housing market conditions from the housing market downturn that began in 2007.
794619_17_ITEM7_P9_S0	A number of general market factors impacted the Company's business in fiscal 2017, including:
794619_17_ITEM7_P10_S0	Cabinet sales, as reported by members of the Kitchen Cabinet Manufacturers Association (KCMA), increased by 4% during fiscal 2017 versus the prior fiscal year, suggesting an increase in both new construction and remodeling sales of cabinets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P11_S0	The Company s largest remodeling customers and competitors continued to utilize sales promotions in the Company s product category during fiscal 2017 to boost sales.
794619_17_ITEM7_P11_S1	The Company strives to maintain its promotional levels in line with market activity, with a goal of remaining competitive.
794619_17_ITEM7_P11_S2	The Company experienced promotional levels during fiscal 2017 that were higher than those experienced in its prior fiscal year.
794619_17_ITEM7_P11_S3	The Company s remodeling sales were flat during fiscal 2017, below the overall remodeling market.
794619_17_ITEM7_P12_S0	The Company increased its net sales by 9% during fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P12_S1	The Company realized strong sales gains in its new construction channel during fiscal 2017, where sales increased by more than 17%, significantly outpacing the improvement in single-family housing starts for the same period.
794619_17_ITEM7_P12_S2	Management believes the Company over indexed the market due to share penetration with our builder partners and the health of the markets where we concentrated our business during fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P13_S0	Gross margin for fiscal 2017 was 21.8%, an improvement from 21.1% in fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P13_S1	The increase in the Company s gross margin rate was driven by the beneficial impact of increased sales volume, lower labor benefit costs and improved operating efficiency.
794619_17_ITEM7_P14_S0	The Company regularly considers the need for a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P15_S0	The Company has been profitable for the last 5 years.
794619_17_ITEM7_P15_S1	As of April 30, 2017, the Company had total deferred tax assets of $27.5 million, down from $41.3 million at April 30, 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P15_S2	The Company's deferred tax assets decreased in fiscal 2017 primarily due to Company contributions to the pension plans as well as better than expected returns from the plans assets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P16_S0	in fiscal 2016 due to an increase in the unfunded pension obligation, as a result of a decrease in the discount rate and the Company updating to the new RP-2014 mortality tables, with generational MP-2015 projections.
794619_17_ITEM7_P16_S1	To fully realize its remaining net deferred tax assets, the Company will need to, among other things, substantially reduce its unfunded pension obligation of $28.0 million at April 30, 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P17_S0	The Company recorded a valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets for certain state investment tax credit (ITC) carryforwards during fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P17_S1	In fiscal 2017, the Company reassessed the valuation allowance related to ITCs and released $0.6 million of the valuation allowance recorded in the fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P18_S0	The Company expects to continue funding its pension plans for the foreseeable future, which will reduce both its unfunded pension plan obligation and its deferred tax asset.
794619_17_ITEM7_P18_S1	The recent improvement in the U.S. housing market and the Company s continued ability to grow its sales at a faster rate than its competitors, enabled the Company to generate net income during fiscal 2017 like it has done since fiscal 2013.
794619_17_ITEM7_P18_S2	The Company believes that the positive evidence of the housing industry improvement, coupled with the benefits from the Company s successful restructuring and continued market share gains have already driven a return to profitability that is expected to continue.
794619_17_ITEM7_P18_S3	Accordingly, Management has concluded it is more likely than not that the Company will realize its deferred tax assets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P19_S0	The Company also regularly assesses its long-lived assets to determine if any impairment has occurred.
794619_17_ITEM7_P19_S1	The Company has concluded that none of the long-lived assets pertaining to its nine manufacturing plants or any of its other long-lived assets were impaired as of April 30, 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P20_S0	Net sales were $1,030.2 million in fiscal 2017, an increase of $83.2 million, or 9%, compared with fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P20_S1	Overall unit volume for fiscal 2017 was 8.0% higher than in fiscal 2016, which was driven primarily by the Company s increased new construction and dealer volume.
794619_17_ITEM7_P20_S2	Average revenue per unit increased 0.8% in fiscal 2017, driven by improvements in the Company s product mix and pricing.
794619_17_ITEM7_P21_S0	Net sales were $947.0 million in fiscal 2016, an increase of $121.6 million, or 15%, compared with fiscal 2015.
794619_17_ITEM7_P21_S1	Overall unit volume for fiscal 2016 was 12% higher than in fiscal 2015, which was driven primarily by the Company s increased new construction and dealer volume.
794619_17_ITEM7_P21_S2	Average revenue per unit increased 3% in fiscal 2016, driven by improvements in the Company s product mix and pricing.
794619_17_ITEM7_P22_S0	Gross profit as a percentage of sales increased to 21.8% in fiscal 2017 as compared with 21.1% in fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P22_S1	The improvement in gross profit margin was due primarily to the beneficial impact of increased sales volume, lower labor benefit costs and improved operating efficiency.
794619_17_ITEM7_P23_S0	During fiscal 2016, the Company s gross profit increased as a percentage of net sales to 21.1% from 18.5% in fiscal 2015.
794619_17_ITEM7_P23_S1	The improvement in gross profit margin was due primarily to the beneficial impact of increased sales volume, customer management, product mix, pricing and improved operating efficiency.
794619_17_ITEM7_P23_S2	This favorability was partially offset by the impact of additional depreciation costs related to the previously announced plant expansion and costs associated with crewing and infrastructure to support higher levels of sales and installation activity.
794619_17_ITEM7_P24_S0	Selling and marketing expenses in fiscal 2017 were 6.9% of net sales, compared with 7.0% of net sales in fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P24_S1	Selling and marketing costs increased only by 7% despite a 9% increase in net sales.
794619_17_ITEM7_P24_S2	The improvement in the percentage of sales and marketing costs in relation to net sales was due to favorable leverage from increased sales, on-going expense control and lower display costs and commissions.
794619_17_ITEM7_P25_S0	Selling and marketing expenses were 7.0% of net sales in fiscal 2016 compared with 7.8% in fiscal 2015.
794619_17_ITEM7_P25_S1	The improvement in the percentage of sales and marketing costs in relation to net sales was due to favorable leverage from increased sales, on-going expense control and lower display and product launch costs.
794619_17_ITEM7_P26_S0	General and administrative expenses increased by $5.4 million or 13.4% during fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P26_S1	The increase was related to increased staffing costs and the incurrence of corporate business development expenses related to a potential M A transaction that we ultimately decided not to pursue.
794619_17_ITEM7_P26_S2	General and administrative costs increased to 4.4% of net sales in fiscal 2017 compared with 4.3% of net sales in fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P27_S0	General and administrative expenses in fiscal 2016 increased by $6.3 million, or 18.6%, compared with fiscal 2015 and represented 4.3% of net sales, compared with 4.1% of net sales for fiscal 2015.
794619_17_ITEM7_P27_S1	The increase in cost was related to increased pay-for-performance compensation and staffing costs.
794619_17_ITEM7_P28_S0	The Company generated pre-tax income of $108.9 million during fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P28_S1	The Company s effective tax rate decreased from 36.0% in fiscal 2016 to 34.6% in fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P28_S2	The lower effective tax rate was primarily due to the benefit from adopting ASU 2016-09 for equity based compensation.
794619_17_ITEM7_P28_S3	The Company s effective tax rate increased from 34.7% in fiscal 2015 to 36.0% in fiscal 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P28_S4	The higher effective tax rate was the result of the Company operating at a higher net income level than the prior year period and less favorable permanent tax differences.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S0	The Company tracks several metrics, including but not limited to housing starts, existing home sales, mortgage interest rates, new jobs growth, GDP growth and consumer confidence, which it believes are leading indicators of overall demand for kitchen and bath cabinetry.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S1	The Company believes that housing starts will continue to improve, driven by low unemployment rates and growth in new household formation.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S2	However, the Company expects that while the cabinet remodeling market will show modest improvement during fiscal 2018 it will continue to be below historical averages.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S3	The Company expects that industry-wide cabinet remodeling sales will continue to be challenged until economic trends remain consistently favorable.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S4	Growth is expected at roughly a mid-single digit rate during the Company s fiscal 2018.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S5	The Company expects its home center market share to remain at normalized levels for fiscal 2018, however this is heavily dependent upon competitive promotional activity, and it will continue to gain market share in its growing dealer business.
794619_17_ITEM7_P29_S6	This combination is expected to result in remodeling sales growth that exceeds the market rate.

794619_17_ITEM7_P51_S0	Management has chosen accounting policies that are necessary to give reasonable assurance that the Company s operational results and financial position are accurately and fairly reported.
794619_17_ITEM7_P51_S1	The significant accounting policies of the Company are disclosed in Note A to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in this annual report.
794619_17_ITEM7_P51_S2	The following discussion addresses the accounting policies that management believes have the greatest potential impact on the presentation of the financial condition and operating results of the Company for the periods being reported and that require the most judgment.
794619_17_ITEM7_P52_S0	Management regularly reviews these critical accounting policies and estimates with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
794619_17_ITEM7_P53_S0	The Company utilizes signed sales agreements that provide for transfer of title to the customer upon delivery.
794619_17_ITEM7_P53_S1	The Company must estimate the amount of sales that have been transferred to third-party carriers but not delivered to customers.
794619_17_ITEM7_P53_S2	The estimate is calculated using a lag factor determined by analyzing the actual difference between shipment date and delivery date of orders over the past 12 months.
794619_17_ITEM7_P54_S0	Revenue is only recognized on those shipments which the Company believes have been delivered to the customer.
794619_17_ITEM7_P55_S0	The Company recognizes revenue based on the invoice price less allowances for sales returns, cash discounts and other deductions as required under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
794619_17_ITEM7_P55_S1	Collection is reasonably assured as determined through an analysis of accounts receivable data, including historical product returns and the evaluation of each customer s ability to pay.
794619_17_ITEM7_P56_S0	Allowances for sales returns are based on the historical relationship between shipments and returns.
794619_17_ITEM7_P56_S1	The Company believes that its historical experience is an accurate reflection of future returns.
794619_17_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company is self-insured for certain costs related to employee medical coverage, workers compensation liability, general liability, auto liability and property insurance.
794619_17_ITEM7_P57_S1	The Company maintains stop-loss coverage with third-party insurers to limit total exposure.
794619_17_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company establishes a liability at each balance sheet date based on estimates for a variety of factors that influence the Company s ultimate cost.
794619_17_ITEM7_P58_S1	In the event that actual experience is substantially different from the estimates, the financial results for the period could be adversely affected.
794619_17_ITEM7_P58_S2	The Company believes that the methodologies used to estimate insurance liabilities are an accurate reflection of the liabilities as of the date of the balance sheet.
794619_17_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company has two non-contributory defined benefit pension plans covering many of the Company s employees hired prior to April 30, 2012.
794619_17_ITEM7_P59_S1	Effective April 30, 2012, the Company froze all future benefit accruals under the Company s hourly and salaried defined benefit pension plans.
794619_17_ITEM7_P60_S0	The estimated expense, benefits and pension obligations of these plans are determined using various assumptions.
794619_17_ITEM7_P60_S1	The most significant assumptions are the long-term expected rate of return on plan assets and the discount rate used to determine the present value of the pension obligations.
794619_17_ITEM7_P61_S0	The long-term expected rate of return on plan assets reflects the current mix of the plan assets invested in equities and bonds.
794619_17_ITEM7_P62_S0	Beginning with the April 30, 2016 measurement, the Company refined the method used to determine the service and interest cost components of its net periodic benefit cost.
794619_17_ITEM7_P62_S1	Previously, the cost was determined using a single weighted-average discount rate derived from the yield curve.
794619_17_ITEM7_P62_S2	Under the refined method, known as the spot rate approach, individual spot rates along the yield curve that correspond with the timing of each benefit payment will be used.
794619_17_ITEM7_P62_S3	The Company believes this change provides a more precise measurement of service and interest costs by improving the correlation between projected cash outflows and corresponding spot rates on the yield curve.
794619_17_ITEM7_P62_S4	Compared to the previous method, the spot rate approach decreased the service and interest components of the benefit costs in fiscal 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P62_S5	There is no impact on the total benefit obligation.
794619_17_ITEM7_P63_S0	The following is a summary of the potential impact of a hypothetical 1% change in actuarial assumptions for the discount rate, expected return on plan assets and consumer price index:
794619_17_ITEM7_P64_S0	Pension expense for fiscal 2017 and the assumptions used in that calculation are presented in Note H of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
794619_17_ITEM7_P65_S0	At April 30, 2017, the weighted average discount rate was 4.12% compared with 4.06% at April 30, 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P65_S1	The expected return on plan assets was 7.5% at both April 30, 2017, and April 30, 2016.

794619_17_ITEM7_P66_S0	The projected performance of the Company s pension plans is largely dependent on the assumptions used to measure the obligations of the plans and to estimate future performance of the plans invested assets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P66_S1	Over the past two measurement periods, the most material deviations between results based on assumptions and the actual plan performance have resulted from changes to the discount rate used to measure the plans benefit obligations and the actual return on plan assets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P67_S0	Accounting guidelines require the discount rate to be set to a current market rate at each annual measurement date.
794619_17_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Company strives to balance expected long-term returns and short-term volatility of pension plan assets.
794619_17_ITEM7_P68_S1	Favorable and unfavorable differences between the assumed and actual returns on plan assets are generally amortized over a period no longer than the average life expectancy of the plans active participants.

794619_17_ITEM7_P70_S1	Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance when, after considering all positive and negative evidence, it is determined that it is more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
794619_17_ITEM7_P71_S0	The Company has recorded a valuation allowance related to deferred tax assets for certain state investment tax credit (ITC) carryforwards.

794619_17_ITEM7_P73_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers: Topic 606.
794619_17_ITEM7_P73_S1	ASU 2014-09 supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in Accounting Standard Codification 605 - Revenue Recognition and most industry-specific guidance.
794619_17_ITEM7_P74_S0	The standard requires that entities recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which a company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
794619_17_ITEM7_P75_S0	ASU 2014-09 permits the use of either the retrospective or cumulative effect transition method.
794619_17_ITEM7_P76_S0	The Company does not expect the adoption of ASU 2014-09 and ASU 2015-14 to have a material impact on results of operations, cash flows and financial position.
794619_17_ITEM7_P76_S1	The Company is continuing to evaluate the impact of ASU 2014-09 primarily to determine the transition method to utilize at adoption and the additional disclosures required.
794619_17_ITEM7_P77_S0	ASU 2016-02 requires lessees to recognize most leases on-balance sheet, which will increase reported assets and liabilities.
794619_17_ITEM7_P78_S0	Lessor accounting remains substantially similar to current U.S. GAAP.
794619_17_ITEM7_P79_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for public companies for annual and interim periods in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018.
794619_17_ITEM7_P80_S0	ASU 2016-02 mandates a modified retrospective transition method for all entities.
794619_17_ITEM7_P80_S1	The Company is currently assessing the impact that ASU 2016-02 will have on its consolidated financial statements, however, if at adoption the Company has similar obligations for leases as it had at April 30, 2017, the Company believes this guidance will not have a material impact on its results of operations, cash flows and financial position.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-09, Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Shares-Based Payment Accounting.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S1	ASU 2016-09 is intended to improve the accounting for share-based payment transactions as part of the FASB s simplification initiative.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S2	ASU 2016-09 changes several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment award transactions, including: (1) accounting for income taxes; (2) classification of excess tax benefits on the statement of cash flows; (3) forfeitures; (4) minimum statutory tax withholding requirements; and (5) classification of employee taxes paid on the statement of cash flows when an employer withholds shares for tax-withholding purposes.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S3	ASU 2016-09 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those years for public companies.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S4	The Company early adopted this standard as of May 1, 2016.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S5	As a result, during fiscal 2017, it recognized the excess tax benefit of $1.3 million as income tax benefit on the condensed consolidated statements of income (adopted prospectively).
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S6	The adoption did not impact the existing classification of the awards.
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S7	Excess tax benefits from stock based compensation is now classified in net income in the statement of cash flows instead of being separately stated in financing activities for the twelve months ended April 30, 2017 (adopted prospectively).
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S8	Additionally, the Company reclassified $2.8 million and $1.4 million of employee withholding taxes paid from operating activities into financing activities in the statement of cash flows for the twelve month periods ended April 30, 2016 and 2015, respectively, as required by ASU 2016-09 (adopted retrospectively).
794619_17_ITEM7_P81_S9	Following the adoption of the new standard, the Company elected to continue estimating the number of awards expected to be forfeited and adjust its estimate on an ongoing basis.
794619_17_ITEM7_P82_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-03, Interest - Imputation of Interest (Subtopic 835-30): Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs.
794619_17_ITEM7_P82_S1	The Company retrospectively adopted this standard on April 30, 2016, which resulted in the reclassification of approximately $0.3 million of debt issuance costs from other assets to long-term debt as of April 30, 2016.

794619_17_ITEM7_P83_S0	In May 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-07, Disclosures for Investments in Certain Entities that Calculate Net Asset Value per Share (or its Equivalent), which amends the disclosure requirements of Accounting Standards Codification Topic 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, for reporting entities that measure the fair value of an investment using the net asset value per share (or its equivalent) as a practical expedient.
794619_17_ITEM7_P83_S1	The amendments in ASU 2015-07 remove the requirement to categorize within the fair value hierarchy all investments for which fair value is measured using the net asset value per share practical expedient and also remove the requirements to make certain disclosures for all investments that are eligible to be measured at fair value using the net asset value per share practical expedient.

794619_17_ITEM7_P84_S0	ASU 2017-07 requires an employer to disaggregate the service cost component from the other components of net benefit (income) cost.
794619_17_ITEM7_P84_S1	The other components of net benefit (income) cost are required to be presented in the income statement separately from the service cost component and outside of operating income.
794619_17_ITEM7_P84_S2	The amendments also allow only the service cost component of net benefit (income) cost to be eligible for capitalization.
794619_17_ITEM7_P84_S3	The amendments in this ASU are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017.
794619_17_ITEM7_P84_S4	The amendments in this ASU should be applied (1) retrospectively for the presentation of the service cost component and the other components of net periodic pension (income) cost and net periodic postretirement benefit (income) cost on the income statement, and (2) prospectively, on and after the effective date, for the capitalization of the service cost component of net periodic pension (income) cost and net periodic postretirement benefit (income) cost in assets.
